Maryland
 A brief flirtation with Republican leadership ended this year with Democrats sweeping major races, including the battles for governor and an open Senate seat. Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., who four years ago became the first Republican elected governor since Spiro Agnew, conceded defeat yesterday morning to Mayor Martin O'Malley of Baltimore, ending the most expensive governor's race in state history. 
 Analysts said Mr. Ehrlich's defeat appeared to be largely about partisan whiplash in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans two to one. ''Ehrlich ran a very competitive race, but partisanship really defeated him,'' said Paul S. Herrnson, a professor of government at the University of Maryland. 
 Benjamin L. Cardin, the longtime Democratic congressman, won a hotly contested race to succeed Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Democrat who is retiring after 30 years. Mr. Cardin defeated Lt. Gov. Michael S. Steele, a Republican, by just over 10 points in a contest pitting issues against image. Mr. Steele, who is black, distanced himself from the party line but had limited success courting black voters and edging away from voter discontent over the war in Iraq. Mr. Cardin voted against the war and played up his educational and environmental record. 
 ''Steele's problem was worse than Ehrlich's,'' said Thomas F. Schaller, a political science professor at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. ''He had to answer questions on Iraq.'' 
 Democrats kept their six-to-two majority in House races, with incumbents winning across the board and John P. Sarbanes, a Democrat and the son of Senator Sarbanes, picking up Mr. Cardin's seat. The Montgomery County state's attorney, Douglas F. Gansler, a Democrat, won the race for attorney general.

Massachusetts
 Ending 16 years of Republican control of the governor's office, Deval Patrick, a former assistant attorney general in the Clinton administration, was elected the Bay State's first black chief executive. Mr. Patrick will be the nation's second black governor since Reconstruction.
 He trounced Lt. Gov. Kerry Healey, a Republican, and two others to succeed Gov. Mitt Romney, who is retiring after one term to explore a presidential run in 2008. The state's last Democratic governor, Michael S. Dukakis, left office in 1991.
 Turnout was so heavy that some Boston precincts ran out of ballots; city officials had replacement ballots delivered in police cruisers.
 Mr. Patrick offered voters a compelling biography. He grew up poor on the South Side of Chicago, received undergraduate and law degrees from Harvard and was the Justice Department's top civil rights officer from 1994 to 1997, before working as a lawyer for Texaco and Coca-Cola. This was his first run for elected office. 
 Although Massachusetts elected Edward W. Brooke, an African-American, attorney general in 1962 and senator in 1966 and 1972, court-ordered desegregation in the 1970s opened an ugly chapter in Boston's racial history.
 Paul Y. Watanabe, a political scientist at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, said Mr. Patrick became a symbol of hope and inclusion, even as he played down the race issue in the campaign.
 Jeffrey M. Berry, a political scientist at Tufts University, credited Mr. Patrick with running a superb primary campaign in which he handily defeated two better-financed opponents. But in the general election, he said, ''Any Democrat probably would have won easily.'' 
 Mr. Patrick faces formidable tasks; perhaps the biggest is putting into effect a landmark law requiring all state residents to obtain health insurance by July. 
 Senator Edward M. Kennedy easily won an eighth term, defeating the Republican Kenneth G. Chase. The state's 10 House incumbents, all Democrats, were re-elected. A ballot measure to allow local authorities to license food stores to sell wine was defeated.

New Hampshire
 New Hampshire was the stage for striking Democratic success Tuesday night, as both House seats, occupied by Republicans, were won by Democrats. The Second District in particular had been viewed as vulnerable in recent weeks, and both parties poured money and celebrity into the state, including a last-minute visit from Laura Bush, the first lady. But it was not enough to stem the rising antiwar sentiment that ultimately contributed to the defeat of both Republicans.
 Paul Hodes captured the Second District seat that Representative Charles Bass had held for 12 years, winning by a larger proportion than expected (52.6 to 45.5 percent). 
 The First District was the bigger shock, as Carol Shea-Porter, a relatively little-known antiwar Democrat, defeated Jeb Bradley, 51.5 to 48.5 percent. 
 ''For a while now, the demographics of the state have been changing -- it has been getting bluer,'' said J. Mark Wrighton, an associate professor of political science at the University of New Hampshire. ''You add to that a fairly popular incumbent Democratic governor and a national tide in favor of the Democratic Party, and you get what happened here in the state last night.''
 Gov. John Lynch easily won re-election over Jim Coburn.

GOVERNOR
100% reporting

Lynch: 298,206 73.9%
Coburn: 105,370 26.1%

New Jersey
 Thomas H. Kean Jr., a Republican, channeled most of his efforts to take away Robert Menendez's Senate seat into portraying Mr. Menendez, a Democrat, as a man of flawed character, more interested in lining his pockets than in promoting the good of his constituents. But in this reliably blue state, voters seemed to care less about possible ethical lapses than the state of President Bush's presidency and the war in Iraq. Those issues, in the end, gave Mr. Menendez the edge.
 Exit polls showed that about half of the voters rated corruption as an ''extremely important'' factor in shaping their decision. Nearly an equal number of them cast their ballot for Mr. Kean as for Mr. Menendez, a sign, perhaps, that mudslinging was not the most effective weapon of either campaign.
 Two-thirds of the voters said they opposed the war in Iraq, and three out of four of them voted for Mr. Menendez, who garnered similarly strong support from those who disapproved of Mr. Bush's presidency. Additionally, Mr. Menendez, who was appointed to the Senate by Gov. Jon S. Corzine in December, drew votes from a traditional Democratic coalition of women and labor. Mr. Kean earned the support of the state's smaller conservative bloc.
 Albio Sires won Mr. Menendez's former House seat in two rounds of balloting that give him the post for the remaining two months of Mr. Menendez's term and the full congressional term, which starts in January. Mr. Sires became the state's second Hispanic elected to Congress.

Menendez: 1,159,642 53.1%
Kean: 973, 895 44.6%

New York
 The transformation of upstate New York from a Republican bastion to fertile ground for Democrats took a leap forward, abetted by the national backlash against the war in Iraq and various Washington scandals.
 Democrats took away three Republican-held Congressional seats and came close to gaining three more -- mostly in traditionally Republican areas -- and captured all the statewide offices for the first time in more than 60 years, building on their usual dominance downstate with powerful performances upstate, as well.
 Eliot Spitzer was elected governor with the largest share of the vote in state history, 69 percent with nearly all precincts reporting, and 63 percent upstate. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won 67 percent of the statewide vote in her re-election, and 60 percent upstate. They each carried 59 counties, losing only three small, rural upstate counties.
 Attorney General-elect Andrew M. Cuomo narrowly carried upstate but comfortably won his race, which until recently was considered a tough contest. Even Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, scarred by recent scandal and threatened with the possibility that he could be removed from office, easily won re-election and ran nearly even with his opponent upstate.
 Democrats took two Congressional races in Republican-leaning regions: Michael Arcuri won the central New York seat held by Sherwood Boehlert, a Republican who is retiring, and John Hall defeated Representative Sue Kelly in the Hudson Valley. Kirsten Gillibrand unseated Representative John E. Sweeney in a solidly Republican district stretching from the Hudson Valley to the Adirondacks.
 Three upstate Republicans -- Representatives James Walsh, Thomas Reynolds and John R. Kuhl -- narrowly survived strong challenges.
 But little changed in the State Legislature, where three decades of divided control will continue, with Republicans ruling in the Senate and Democrats in the Assembly.

Pennsylvania
 Democrats scored big victories, toppling a conservative Republican senator, ousting four Republican House members and trouncing a Republican who challenged the state's popular governor.
 The senator, Rick Santorum, held the No. 3position in the Senate Republican leadership and was an outspoken opponent of abortion rights and gay marriage.
 Bob Casey, the state treasurer and son of a former governor, easily defeated Mr. Santorum, whom he described as a rubber stamp for the Bush administration.
 After representing Pittsburgh suburbs in the House for six years, Representative Melissa A. Hart, a Republican, lost to Jason Altmire, a former health care executive and onetime aide to a Democratic member of Congress.
 In Bucks County, outside Philadelphia, a freshman Republican, Representative Michael G. Fitzpatrick, was narrowly defeated by the Democratic challenger, Patrick Murphy, an Iraq war veteran and former prosecutor. Mr. Murphy's antiwar message resonated with many voters.
 The other Republicans who lost their seats, Representatives Curt Weldon and Don Sherwood, were touched by scandal.
 Federal agents are investigating whether Mr. Weldon used his influence to help his daughter, a registered lobbyist, win consulting contracts.
 Mr. Weldon, a 10-term veteran representing a suburban district outside Philadelphia, was defeated by Joe Sestak, a retired vice admiral. 
 In the northeast corner of Pennsylvania, Christopher Carney, a Democrat, unseated Mr. Sherwood, a four-term veteran who acknowledged having an extramarital affair with a Peruvian immigrant less than half his age. Mr. Carney, an associate professor at Pennsylvania State, once worked at the Pentagon. 
 In the Sixth District, Lois Murphy, a lawyer and Democrat, narrowly lost her bid to oust Representative Jim Gerlach, a Republican who won a third term. 
 Gov. Edward G. Rendell, a Democrat, easily beat back a Republican challenge from Lynn Swann, a former football star with the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Rhode Island
 Senator Lincoln Chafee, the most liberal Republican in the Senate and a vocal opponent of the war in Iraq, was widely admired throughout the state.
 But in a state where 63 percent of voters told exit pollsters they wanted the Senate to change hands, and where registered Democrats outnumbered Republicans by more than three to one, Mr. Chafee's party affiliation was enough to get him voted out of office. 
 He will be succeeded by Sheldon Whitehouse, a former state attorney general and former United States attorney whose positions on the issues have been indistinguishable from Mr. Chafee's in many respects. He is a Democrat.
 Throughout the campaign, Mr. Whitehouse held up Mr. Chafee as a supporter of President Bush and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, and their policies, despite Mr. Chafee's record of against-the-grain votes. 
 Mr. Rumsfeld's resignation yesterday buoyed Mr. Whitehouse further. 
 ''The Democrats campaigned on a promise that we could bring change,'' Mr. Whitehouse said. ''I didn't quite expect it to happen so fast.''
 His victory ended three decades of Chafees representing Rhode Island in the Senate. Mr. Chafee took the seat in 1999 after his father, John H. Chafee, died in office. The elder Chafee had held the seat since 1976.
 Democrats poured money into Rhode Island and mounted one of their most successful get-out-the-vote operations there. It was almost strong enough to sweep away the Republican governor, but with 51 percent of the vote, Gov. Donald L. Carcieri squeaked out a victory over the Democratic lieutenant governor, Charles Fogarty.
 The state's two Democratic congressmen were easily re-elected.
 Voters rejected a proposal to give the Narragansett Indian tribe and Harrah's exclusive rights to operate a casino. The measure failed with 63 percent of voters rejecting it. Opponents had criticized it as a ''no-bid deal'' for Harrah's.

Vermont
 In the Senate race, Vermont voters embraced their state's independent streak, electing Representative Bernard Sanders, a longtime independent who proudly calls himself a ''democratic socialist,'' to succeed Senator James M. Jeffords, who is retiring. 
 Mr. Sanders defeated Richard Tarrant, a Republican businessman who spent $7 million of his own money on the race. Mr. Sanders promised to fight for the interests of working families and immigrants and to work to end the war in Iraq. 
 Mr. Jeffords left the Republican Party in 2001 -- a defection that turned control of the Senate over to the Democrats for 19 months. He is retiring for health reasons.
 State Senator Peter Welch, a Democrat, won the House seat vacated by Mr. Sanders. Mr. Welch defeated Martha T. Rainville, a Republican who recently retired as adjutant general of the Vermont National Guard.
 Gov. James Douglas, a Republican, easily won re-election by defeating Scudder Parker, a former state senator and former chairman of the state Democratic Party. 
 This means that one of the few places where Howard Dean, the national Democratic Party leader, cannot boast of winning the governor's mansion is in his home state.

West Virginia
 Senator Robert C. Byrd, first elected to the House in 1952 and to the Senate in 1958, is the longest-serving senator in United States history and a few years shy of having the longest Congressional tenure. He easily won a ninth term, defeating John R. Raese, a businessman and former state Republican chairman. 
 The victory came after a campaign that like many others nationwide had its nastier moments. At one point Mr. Raese disparaged the physical condition of Mr. Byrd, who is 88. And Mr. Byrd had suggested earlier that his opponent's late father would be ashamed of his son's candidacy. 
 All three House incumbents, two Democrats and one Republican, were re-elected.

SECTION: Section A; Column 4; Editorial Desk; Pg. 32

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: The Democrats' Jolt to the Political Landscape

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Democrats Take House'' (front page, Nov. 8):
 So President Bush is not ''the decider.'' We, the American people, are -- as it was meant to be. 

Emily Rome
New York, Nov. 8, 2006

To the Editor:
 I watched, disheartened, as our country grew sicker and sicker. On Tuesday, it proved that its legendary self-healing abilities were still in good working order. 

Anne Bernays
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 8, 2006

To the Editor:
 Now that our electorate has finally woken from its stupor, we should ask ourselves why it took six years to recognize the incompetence and demagogy of this administration and the responsibility of the Republican leadership that blindly followed its lead. 
 The damage done is enormous, in Iraq, in the United States and around the world. Years have been squandered while the critical issues of our time have gone unattended. 
 How and why were we fooled?
 We have a fascination with personalities instead of policy, a desire to be entertained rather than enlightened, and a need to have an enemy to define us and give our lives meaning.
 Thankfully, our democracy is still functioning, though we will not see really meaningful progress until we can disconnect the electoral and legislative processes from the flow of corporate cash. 
 Let's not forget that the Senate voted to give President Bush authority to start a war in Iraq. Our euphoria should be short-lived, and our vigilance should be redoubled.

Ken Swensen
Pound Ridge, N.Y., Nov. 8, 2006

To the Editor:
 Re ''A Loud Message for Bush'' (news analysis, front page, Nov. 8):
 It's almost too good to believe the American people have done the ''almost'' impossible using the greatest democratic process known to man, the vote! 
 A president so convinced of his power and his mandate has been handed a message: ''You wasted your power and your mandate to act without consensus. The people have shouted, Enough! No more abuses of the Constitution and our freedoms; no more disregard for the values our forefathers fought hard to establish; no more 'I am, therefore I can!' ''
 Thank you, my fellow Americans, for taking back our great country and for putting us back on the path to leadership and greatness in America and the world!

Doris Fenig
Floral Park, Queens, Nov. 8, 2006

 Here's why we Democrats won: For six years, even though the Republicans barely won their elections (if they won at all: see the 2000 election), they have disregarded us, scorned us and demonized us.
 The debacle in Iraq is not the problem; it's a symptom of profound arrogance. Here's the ''loud message'': We don't like being ignored.

To the Editor:
 The shift in power in Washington is the result of a desire by midterm voters to cut the engines of President Bush's wayward ship of state.
 That most of us regard the present course as being disastrous is shown by the fact that we made this change with no clear, unified ideas as to how to plot a better path.
 We can only hope that the White House will get the message, accept this verdict and unbend somewhat from its rigid ideology.
 While there is certainly a need for an accounting by the Bush administration on many matters, the investigative powers that the Democrats have gained are not means for revenge. 
 Any true wrongdoing must be brought to justice, of course, but our most immediate goal should be to stanch the bleeding in Iraq.
 As is so often the case, the way out of this mess seems to lie somewhere in the middle ground. We must all be prepared for sacrifice, to seek compromise where we can find it and tolerance where we can't.
 Like it or not, we are all Americans, all with a common fate. And we're in trouble.

Reese Lloyd

 Also, with the election out of the way, the Democrats will have less need to carp at the administration; at the very least, they should start coming up with some solutions of their own.

To the Editor:
 As a liberal independent who generally but not always votes Democratic, I'd like to be jubilant about the results from Tuesday's election. But I can't be.
 Over the last six years, this administration has done perhaps irreparable damage to our international relations, our constitutional guarantees, our economy, our credibility on human rights, our middle class and working poor, and the environment.
 Above all, I mourn the ordinary people, Iraqi and American, killed needlessly in the administration's wrong-footed adventure in Iraq.
 I'm sure that the Democrats are sharpening their knives for their new day of leadership. Doubtless, the public will learn many disturbing things about the way our country has been run by this government.
 But this president and his enablers will continue to insist that their theory of a unitary presidency should trump every attempt to bring them to heel. They will, for example, resist every investigation, arguing that the only check on the president's power is the voters' power to displace him. 
 That opportunity was lost forever in 2004.
 The adults stand again in the doorway of the nursery, surveying the wreckage. Perhaps we can repair this mess, but I am not optimistic.

HEADLINE: As Man of the Hour and Chairman-to-Be, Rangel Is on the Move 

BYLINE: By ERIC KONIGSBERG

 BODY:
Representative Charles B. Rangel's Town Car was doing the late-afternoon creep down Fifth Avenue yesterday, ferrying him from a conference call in his Harlem office (87 political reporters on the line at once) to a live television appearance at the Fox News studios in Midtown, when he glanced at his phone list.
 These were the calls congratulating him on his impending ascension, with the previous night's Democratic takeover of the House of Representatives, to chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee. These were calls he had to return, more than 100 since 9 a.m. But there was one particular well-wisher he was eager to get on the line: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr.
 ''Mr. Secretary, I been using your name all over the press saying I'm looking forward to sitting down with you,'' Mr. Rangel said into his cellphone. ''Finding out what your priorities are and how we can work together.'' 
 There was a silence while Mr. Paulson got in a few words. Mr. Rangel thanked him and hung up. Then he launched into his best imitation of a buttoned-up treasury secretary by way of Wall Street.
 '' 'We had a bad night last night, but I couldn't think of anybody I'd rather have as chairman of Ways and Means than you,' '' Mr. Rangel said. Then, in his own voice, he added, ''He already told me that before.''
 Mr. Rangel, 76, has been waiting for this moment a long time. In 1970, he defeated the long-serving Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and went to Washington to represent Harlem. Four years later, he got a seat on Ways and Means, which writes tax policy and oversees some of the federal government's largest entitlement programs. It was not an easy appointment to get, he recalled.
 ''Oh my God, I had the support of Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay to get on Ways and Means,'' he said. ''They were telling me I had to get on the committee to help the city. I got on to fill the vacancy left by Hugh Carey when he ran for governor. He told me I didn't endorse him until he provided me a seat on Ways and Means. I forgot about that: he's right.''
 The chairman-to-be raised his eyebrows in a manner that might be described as impish, if it were possible to imagine an imp with a bushy mustache and that slicked-back silver pompadour. Just days ago, the suggestion that a Bush administration official, much less the treasury secretary, might call to congratulate Mr. Rangel for becoming Ways and Means chairman might have seemed a bad joke. Throughout the final weeks of the campaign, the president, the vice president and legions of less prominent Republicans had warned in dire tones that a Rangel-led committee would lead the country to economic disaster. 
 ''Charlie doesn't understand how the economy works,'' Vice President Dick Cheney said in one such blast, all but promising ''a big tax increase'' if Mr. Rangel became the committee chairman.
 Mr. Rangel, who won re-election on Tuesday with 94 percent of the vote, is quick to emphasize that the years following the Gingrich revolution of 1994 made the House a lot less fun.
 ''The leadership was not interested in working together,'' he said. ''They wanted to make political statements. The frustration was so deep. I felt like I was in a house that was on fire. I was on patrol with the fire department and I had a hose, but no water came out of it.'' 
 Even so, Mr. Rangel said yesterday that he had every intention of working with Republicans to return bipartisan civility to the House. 
 ''My biggest job is convincing the Democrats, the young people especially, not to try to get even if we want to get something done,'' he said. ''Hopefully, we can find some noncontroversial issues to start with. I used to work very well with Republicans, you know. Of course, many of those people are gone now.''
 One such Republican, Clay Shaw of Florida, would have been the ranking minority member on Ways and Means, had he not lost on Tuesday in a close race. ''Charlie and I have been close friends for years, which is all too rare today,'' Mr. Shaw. 
 Together, Mr. Shaw said, they had been hoping to organize weekend retreats for committee members, get rid of the Alternative Minimum Tax and add investment opportunities to the Social Security program.
 Mr. Shaw was asked what he felt Mr. Rangel's chances were of bringing harmony to the committee. ''Well, if the ranking member is for it,'' he said. ''And of course, that won't be me.''
 In the car, Mr. Rangel said that he was not going to try to increase taxes. ''Yeah, right,'' he said. ''With the presidential veto? Of course I'm not raising taxes.''
 He returned another call, this one to Keller George, an Oneida tribal leader. ''George is going to get me a DNA test,'' Mr. Rangel said. ''I need a casino.''
 Mr. Rangel and his driver, Al, both laughed, and the moment seemed to shake him loose from the constrictions of his statesman's mantle. A moment or two later, he was asked what he thought of making President Bush's tax cuts permanent rather than allowing them to expire in 2010.
 He gave a look of mock reproach.
 ''Oh, don't do that,'' he said. ''I'm trying to start out nice here.
 ''But I'll tell you, I was just watching the president's news conference on television. It looks like he's having a little fit up there. Those exaggerated head movements. I felt so sorry for him. He acted like he didn't know where he was.''
 As for Mr. Cheney, Mr. Rangel said: ''I don't have any problem with him.'' In fact, Mr. Rangel was surprised that Mr. Cheney had singled him out in his late-campaign stump speeches. ''He doesn't normally get involved with any of this tax stuff. He's just war, war, war.''
 Mr. Rangel said he was very interested in the future use of a special room, situated on the second floor of the United States Capitol, that Representative Bill Thomas, the current Ways and Means chairman, has allowed Mr. Cheney to use. 
 ''I wonder what's going to happen to that office,'' Mr. Rangel said. ''I wonder. It's going to be my office. That's right, it is.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: CENTER OF ATTENTION -- Charles B. Rangel, of Harlem, center, is in step to head the Ways and Means Committee. Left, Representative Clay Shaw, a Florida Republican, and Benjamin L. Cardin, a Maryland Democrat. (Photo by Dennis Cook/Associated Press)

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 3353 words

HEADLINE: West

BYLINE: By Vikas Bajaj, Julie Bosman, Sewell Chan, Sam Dillon, David M. Herszenhorn, Andy Newman, Robert Pear, Richard Perez-Pena, Ray Rivera and Fernanda Santos contributed to this report.

 BODY:

A blue streak sweeps through the region, and a victory in a hotly contested Senate race takes center stage, announcing a new breed of Democrat.

Alaska
 Sarah Palin, a Republican and former mayor of an Anchorage suburb, became Alaska's first female governor, fighting off a comeback bid by Tony Knowles, a Democrat and former governor. Ms. Palin, a social and fiscal conservative who calls herself a ''hockey mom,'' rose to prominence by uncovering misconduct in the administration of Gov. Frank Murkowski, whom she later trounced in the Republican primary in August.
Mr. Knowles had called Ms. Palin inexperienced and said he was better positioned to help the state profit from its natural gas reserves, but Ms. Palin beat him by eight percentage points. 
 Representative Don Young, a congressman since 1973, was easily re-elected. 

GOVERNOR
99.5% reporting
Palin: 99,145 48.7%
Knowles: 82,956 40.7%

Arizona
 
 Immigration dominated the political discourse in Arizona, from a number of ballot initiatives to the closely watched Senate race. Republicans positioned themselves as hard-liners on immigration, and for Senator Jon Kyl, the incumbent Republican, the strategy paid off. He gained almost a 9-point victory against his Democratic challenger, Jim Pederson, a developer and former state Democratic Party chairman. 
 Mr. Kyl's win was a major victory for the Republicans, who lost crucial Senate races across the country and could not afford to lose a seat that was, not so long ago, solidly Republican. 
 One House seat in the spotlight was held by Representative J. D. Hayworth, a Republican first elected in 1994. But he lost to Harry Mitchell, a former state Democratic Party chairman, 50 percent to 46 percent. 
 Gov. Janet Napolitano, a Democrat, easily held onto her seat by an almost 28-point margin against Len Munsil, a Republican. 
 Immigration was an issue in several ballot initiatives, directly or indirectly. Seventy-four percent of the voters approved an initiative to make English the state's official language, but most Hispanic voters disapproved of the measure. The voters overwhelmingly passed Proposition 100, which would ban the opportunity for bail to illegal immigrants. 
 Voters narrowly rejected a measure that banned same-sex marriage, approved a measure to raise the minimum wage, passed an antismoking measure and rejected a measure that, in the hopes of increasing voter participation, would have established a $1 million ''voter reward'' lottery.

SENATE
100% reporting
Kyl: 607,778 52.8%
Pederson: 506,759 44%

GOVERNOR
100% reporting
Napolitano: 727,739 62.9%
Munsil: 405, 456 35.1%

California
 Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger found the formula for winning as a Republican in this state that usually goes against his party: sound like a Democrat.
 Deeply unpopular less than a year ago, the governor courted the mostly Democratic Legislature, criticized President Bush and signed bills to raise the minimum wage and combat global warming. The result was a resounding victory over State Treasurer Phil Angelides as Republicans around the country -- and even around his state -- struggled.
 The national tide was seen most clearly in the re-election races of two Republican congressmen with districts near Sacramento that would usually be safe for them. Representative Richard Pombo, under fire for ties to the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, lost to a Democrat, Gerald McNerney. And Representative John Doolittle narrowly won re-election over his Democratic challenger, Charlie Brown.
 Aside from governor, Democrats won six of the seven races for statewide office; they included former Gov. Jerry Brown, elected attorney general. Senator Dianne Feinstein was re-elected with almost 60 percent of the vote, the best showing in decades by a Senate candidate, in defeating Dick Mountjoy.
 Californians upheld their reputation for frequent and unpredictable use of the initiative process, voting on 13 ballot measures and taking liberal stances on some and conservative ones on others.
 They rejected an initiative to require parental notification before a minor can have an abortion and one to limit government's power of eminent domain. They also voted to reject public campaign financing, and to toughen penalties for sex offenders and require them to submit to lifetime Global Positioning System monitoring. Yesterday, a federal judge blocked enforcement of the sex offender law, ruling that it was probably unconstitutional, and ordered a hearing later this month.
 The voters also continued a pattern of being averse to taxes, but amenable to higher state debt. They approved $37 billion in borrowing through bond acts for highways, housing, schools and levees, but rejected taxes on cigarettes and oil production.

99.5% reporting
Feinstein: 3,983,385 59.7%
Mountjoy: 2,324,856 34.8%

4TH DIST.

11TH DIST.
100% reporting

Pombo: 77,669 46.9%

Colorado
 The last time Colorado Democrats elected a governor and majorities in both houses of the legislature was 1958. So the election of Bill Ritter, a former Denver prosecutor, to the Colorado Statehouse felt like a watershed, capping a four-year string of Democratic victories that has turned a red state into one that is more blue.
 But the Colorado electorate did not vote in the way, say, California Democrats might have. The same night the state elected Mr. Ritter governor, and increased to four the Democrats' share of Colorado's seven-member Congressional delegation, voters also approved a constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage and rejected proposals to extend many basic legal rights to same-sex couples and to legalize marijuana.
 ''This is a centrist electorate,'' said Floyd Ciruli, an independent pollster based in Denver. ''In this election, voters punished Republicans, but they'll keep Democrats on a short leash unless they approach their victories cautiously.''
 Mr. Ritter, who won more than 56 percent of the vote in defeating Representative Bob Beauprez, a Republican, was born and reared on a Colorado farm. He has said that he is against abortion but committed to upholding the right of women to seek one. He portrayed himself as tough on crime but pragmatic on immigration, arguing that the construction and farm industries were being hurt by strict new immigration laws. He advocated a strong role for government in solving public problems.
 That centrist stance contrasted with Mr. Beauprez's image as a hard-line social and fiscal conservative who once backed a measure that threatened to shut down community colleges or allow state roads to go unrepaired. Independent voters supported Mr. Ritter by a huge margin.
 ''As Republicans, we've got some work to do,'' Mr. Beauprez said in his concession speech. ''There's a bit of a wind blowing out there, and it's not necessarily a warm, friendly wind.''
 In House races, the former State Senator Ed Perlmutter, a Democrat, defeated Rick O'Donnell, the Republican former chairman of a state education commission.

GOVERNOR
97.9% reporting
Ritter: 779,741 56.3%
Beauprez: 566,303 40.9%

7TH DIST.
99.7% reporting
Perlmutter: 99,824 54.8%
O'Donnell: 76,825 42.2%

Hawaii
 There was little suspense about the outcomes of the races for governor, Senate and the two House seats in Hawaii. 
 Senator Daniel K. Akaka, a Democrat, easily held back his Republican challenger, State Representative Cynthia Thielen, to capture his third full term. He immediately renewed his promise to make the war in Iraq, which he opposes, his first priority. Gov. Linda Lingle, a Republican, overcame Hawaiian voters' anti-Republican mood to win her second term, defeating Randy Iwase. 
 Mazie Hirono, a Democrat and former lieutenant governor, defeated Bob Hogue to win the House seat in the largely Democratic Second District. In the First District, Neil Abercrombie, a Democrat, won his 9th consecutive term and 10th over all.

SENATE
99.4% reporting

GOVERNOR
99.4% reporting

Idaho
 This heavily Republican state had two surprisingly close races. 
 In one, a three-term Republican congressman, C. L. Otter, known as Butch, defeated a Democratic newspaper publisher, Jerry M. Brady, in the race for governor. The current governor, James E. Risch -- a Republican who took office in May after his predecessor, Dirk Kempthorne, became the United States interior secretary -- decided not to seek a full term but to run instead for his former job as lieutenant governor. 
 In the western of Idaho's two House districts, which Mr. Otter represents, State Representative Bill Sali, a Republican, narrowly beat Larry Grant, a Democratic lawyer. Mr. Sali, who emerged from a divisive primary with many enemies within his party, was seen as vulnerable; Vice President Dick Cheney campaigned with him, and national Republicans paid for advertisements attacking Mr. Grant.
 ''The Democrats have been closing the get-out-the-vote gap in Idaho, and yet it wasn't enough,'' said Douglas C. Nilson, a political scientist at Idaho State University, in Pocatello. ''Last-minute Republican attack ads really helped.''
 Solid majorities approved a constitutional ban on same-sex marriage and rejected a proposition to limit the use of eminent domain for economic development. 
 ''We are the reddest of the red states,'' said Todd Shallat, the director of the Center for Idaho History and Politics at Boise State University. ''We're dealing with God, guns and gays. At a time when the whole nation, even in Montana, was sending Republicans packing, the Republicans swept every statewide office here.'' 
 But Mr. Shallat, a historian, said the state's demographics were changing. Boise, the capital and largest city, is growing rapidly with migrants from the Pacific Northwest and Southern California, and now leans Democratic, and an influx of Latino immigrants statewide could make future races more competitive.

Grant: 99,687 44.7%

Montana
 Jon Tester, a new-style Western Democrat, narrowly won his Senate race against Conrad Burns, the Republican incumbent, who had been seeking his fourth term. The victory secured at least a 50-50 tie for the Democrats in the Senate and capped a fierce contest crucial to the party's hopes of gaining control of Congress.
 Mr. Tester, the president of the State Senate, is a farmer and a part-time butcher who often waved to voters with his left hand, showing where he had lost three fingers in a meat grinder. He is a macho Rocky Mountain politician whose image was molded after his patron, Gov. Brian Schweitzer. 
 Mr. Tester's win and the victory by Bill Ritter, the Democrat in the Colorado governor's race, amounted to major triumphs for Mr. Schweitzer. 
 Mr. Schweitzer has been promoting a new image for the Democratic Party in the Rocky Mountain West, with candidates strong on gun rights and environmental protection, against free-trade deals and in favor of the death penalty, lower taxes and abortion rights.
 States once taken for granted as Republican strongholds now have a blue Democratic streak running through them.
 Mr. Burns, who as of yesterday evening had not conceded the race, was hurt by his ties to Jack Abramoff, the convicted lobbyist, having received more money from Mr. Abramoff than any other Republican. 
 Recent visits by President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney did not help Mr. Burns and might even have hurt. In exit polls, 60 percent of voters said they believed that Mr. Burns had been in office too long, and 55 percent said they disapproved of Mr. Bush's performance. 
 Voters approved an increase in the minimum wage to $6.15 and a measure banning certain state officials from becoming lobbyists too soon after leaving their government jobs. The Republican representative, Denny Rehberg, easily won re-election.

SENATE
100% reporting
Tester: 198,302 49.1%
Burns: 195,455 48.4%

Nevada
 Rural voters proved critical in Representative Jim Gibbons's triumph in the governor's race. 
 Mr. Gibbons, a Republican from Reno, defeated his Democratic opponent, State Senate Minority Leader Dina Titus, a political science professor from Las Vegas.
 ''We have one of the most solid Republican bases in the rural counties, and thank God for our rural counties,'' Paul Adams, chairman of the Nevada Republican Party, said yesterday.
 Mr. Gibbons's lead had narrowed significantly in the last month after a waitress said he had tried to force himself on her in a parking garage. The accusation, which Mr. Gibbons has denied, is under investigation.
 Senator John Ensign, a Republican, comfortably defeated Jack Carter, a Democrat who is the son of former President Jimmy Carter. And the Republicans maintained their 2-to-1 advantage in the state's House delegation.
 The Republicans also held control of the State Senate, but lost four of six statewide offices: attorney general, secretary of state, comptroller and treasurer. 
 Mr. Adams attributed the losses to ''voters looking for some change.'' Democrats maintained control of the state assembly, picking up one seat each in both houses of the Legislature.
 Voters approved an increase in the state's minimum wage, to $6.15 an hour from $5.15 an hour, for employees who do not have health benefits. The measure calls for further increases if the federal minimum wage is raised and in years when inflation is greater than 3 percent.
 Nevadans also approved a proposed constitutional amendment that would restrict the use of eminent domain; by state law, they must approve it once more before it can take effect. 
 And voters rejected separate ballot proposals that would have legalized marijuana and barred smoking in public places.

SENATE
100% reporting
Ensign: 321,186 55.4%

GOVERNOR
100% reporting
Gibbons: 277,855 47.9%
Titus: 254,920 43.9%

New Mexico
 One of the nation's tightest House races was still undecided yesterday.
 With 99 percent of precincts reporting, the Republican incumbent in the district around Albuquerque, Heather A. Wilson, led the Democratic attorney general, Patricia A. Madrid, by 1,364 votes. But thousands of ballots remained to be tallied in Bernalillo County, which includes Albuquerque and has far more registered Democrats than Republicans. The county clerk told The Associated Press that the counting would not be completed until tomorrow.
 Iraq was a hot topic in the campaign to represent the district, which has sent Republicans to the House for nearly 40 years. Ms. Wilson, a four-term incumbent and a former staff member of the National Security Council, sits on the House Intelligence Committee. And Ms. Madrid, who has served two terms as the attorney general, held Ms. Wilson partly to blame for inaccurate reports on Iraq's weapons programs. 
 New Mexico's Democratic senator, Jeff Bingaman, easily defeated Allen W. McCulloch, a Republican. The Democratic governor, Bill Richardson, routed John Dendahl, a Republican. The state's other two representatives -- Tom Udall, a Democrat, and Steve Pearce, a Republican -- also won re-election.

Oregon
It was a good night for the Democrats in Oregon. The party will control both legislative chambers and the governor's mansion for the first time since 1990.
 Gov. Theodore R. Kulongoski, a Democrat, won a second term, and Democrats kept control of the State Senate. But they won a majority in the State House, which was controlled by Republicans. 
 By a vote of 55 percent to 45 percent, Oregonians turned down a ballot proposal that required parental notification when girls ages 15 to 17 sought abortions. They overwhelmingly approved a separate measure under which the state will use its purchasing power to negotiate discounts on prescription drugs for state residents who have no insurance coverage for them.
 The Republican candidate for governor, Ron Saxton, had described Mr. Kulongoski as a lackluster leader. But the governor took the election results as a vote of confidence. Voters rejected two ballot measures that imposed new financial constraints on the governor's plans for more spending on schools and universities, health care and public safety. Mr. Kulongoski acknowledged that some of his proposals would require higher taxes.
 All five members of the state's Congressional delegation were re-elected. The four Democrats are in line for more influential committee and subcommittee positions.

GOVERNOR
78.4% reporting
Kulongoski: 566,139 51.3%
Saxton: 470,138 42.6%

Utah
 Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the ranking Republican on the Finance and Judiciary Committees, easily won a sixth term, defeating a Democratic opponent, Peter Ashdown, the founder of an Internet service provider. All three House incumbents, two Republicans and one Democrat, were re-elected.

SENATE
100% reporting
Hatch: 343,372 62.6%
Ashdown: 169,034 30.8%

Washington
 Maria Cantwell fell victim to the changing balance of power in Congress in 1994, when Republicans swept Democrats from control and she lost her seat after one term. Ms. Cantwell retreated from politics, only to return in 2000 and eke out a victory for the Senate seat held by Slade Gorton, the Republican.
 This time, empowered by voters' disapproval of the national Republican leadership, and as an incumbent senator, Ms. Cantwell sailed to re-election by a solid margin over the challenger, Mike McGavick, a Republican businessman.
 At her victory celebration in Seattle, when it was clear that Democrats had won control of the House, Ms. Cantwell told supporters, ''We're going to change the course in our country because tonight we're changing who is in charge.'' 
 According to a poll by The Associated Press, nearly two-thirds of Washington voters said they disapproved of the war in Iraq and President Bush's performance, and most of them said they had cast ballots for Ms. Cantwell. 
 Mr. McGavick, an outspoken critic of the Bush administration, drew most of his support from voters who strongly backed the president, according to the poll. 
 The only one of the state's nine House races not called as of yesterday evening was in the Eighth District, where Dave Reichert, a Republican seeking a second term, held a slight lead over Darcy Burner, a Democrat and former Microsoft executive. In the other races, the incumbents, six Democrats and two Republicans, prevailed.
 Ballot initiatives to repeal the estate tax and regulate eminent domain were defeated.
 The fate of a measure promoting clean energy remained unclear; voters appeared to be narrowly favoring it as of late yesterday evening.

SENATE
54% reporting
Cantwell: 659,011 57%
McGavick: 451,748 39%

8TH DIST.
47.6% reporting
Reichert: 61,921 51.1%

Wyoming
 The race for Wyoming's only House seat was not settled as of yesterday evening, but the Republican incumbent, Representative Barbara Cubin, was leading the Democratic challenger, Gary Trauner, by fewer than 1,000 votes. Ms. Cubin declared victory in an interview with The Associated Press, but Mr. Trauner had not conceded. Wyoming election officials said yesterday that the vote margin was just wide enough to avoid an automatic recount. However, either candidate can request one. 
 Ms. Cubin swept into the House in 1994 as part of Newt Gingrich's ''Republican Revolution.'' But her sometimes caustic personality appeared to turn off some voters. 
 After a contentious debate in October, she reportedly told the Libertarian candidate, Thomas Rankin, who has multiple sclerosis, that if he were not in a wheelchair she would ''slap'' him. 
 ''It's things like that that have not played well,'' said Thomas Seitz, a professor of political science at the University of Wyoming.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 22, 2006

 CORRECTION:
A report about Nevada in the State by State election summary on Thursday referred incompletely to voting on smoking in public places. The ballot had two measures to ban smoking, not one. The more restrictive of the two measures was approved. Voters did not reject a ban.
Reports about Washington State in the State by State election summary on Nov. 8 and 9 referred incorrectly to a voter initiative on property rights, which was defeated. The measure would make governments pay for enacting zoning restrictions that reduce the value of private land; it would not regulate eminent domain.

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE; Pg. 12

HEADLINE: Midwest

BYLINE: By Vikas Bajaj, Julie Bosman, Sewell Chan, Sam Dillon, David M. Herszenhorn, Andy Newman, Robert Pear, Richard Perez-Pena, Ray Rivera and Fernanda Santos contributed to this report.

 BODY:

Across the heartland, Democrats make strides at the expense of moderates and incumbents in the Republican Party.

Illinois
 The race to fill the open House seat being vacated by the Republican elder statesman Henry J. Hyde became less meaningful for Democrats after they took control of the lower chamber with key victories in other states.
 But losing it stung the Democrats nonetheless after they spent millions to support a hand-picked candidate whose compelling personal story drew national and international attention.
Tammy Duckworth lost both her legs when a National Guard helicopter she was piloting was shot down near Baghdad in 2004. Recruited by national Democrats to challenge for Mr. Hyde's Sixth District seat, she campaigned with her prosthetic legs and in a wheelchair and became a powerful symbol of the country's growing discontent over President Bush's policy in Iraq. 
 But her strong showing wasn't enough to overcome State Senator Peter Roskam's home-field advantage in suburban DuPage County west of Chicago, a heavily Republican area that kept Mr. Hyde in power for 32 years. Mr. Roskam, who supported the president, won by less than 3 percent of the vote. 
 In another closely contested House race, the Democratic incumbent, Melissa Bean, retained her Eighth District seat with 51 percent of the vote, beating David McSweeney. 
 Democrats also earned a key victory in the governor's race, with the incumbent, Rod R. Blagojevich, winning a second term despite a campaign marred by scandal. Mr. Blagojevich's administration is under federal investigation for allegations of hiring fraud and a kickback scheme in a pension program. 
 His Republican challenger, State Treasurer Judy Baar Topinka, tried to make the race a referendum on Mr. Blagojevich's ethics, but had to fend off attacks over her ties to former Gov. George Ryan, who was convicted on charges of federal racketeering and fraud. 
 But voter concerns over corruption apparently did not weigh heavily enough to unseat Mr. Blagojevich, who won by 10 percentage points.

Indiana
 Indiana, which along with Kentucky had the earliest poll closings in the country, proved to be a bellwether for Democratic victories nationwide. 
 In the Eighth Congressional District, nicknamed the Bloody Eighth because of its history of close races, the outcome was anything but. Brad Ellsworth, a conservative Democrat, trounced John Hostettler, the six-term Republican, who had a reputation as a colorful maverick. He once took a gun to the Louisville airport and said he had forgotten that it was in his briefcase.
 Mr. Ellsworth, the sheriff of Vanderburgh County, was one of three Democrats who ousted incumbents in this traditionally Republican state. Mr. Ellsworth and Mr. Hostettler agreed on many issues, opposing abortion rights, for instance, favoring gun rights and calling for tougher enforcement of immigration laws. A major difference was Mr. Ellsworth's support for an increase in the minimum wage, which Mr. Hostettler opposed. 
 In the Second District, Joe Donnelly, a lawyer and businessman, defeated Chris Chocola, who had been seeking a third term. In the Ninth District, Baron Hill, a former two-term congressman, took back the seat from Mike Sodrel, who won it from Mr. Hill in 2004. 
 Six incumbent representatives, four Republicans and two Democrats, won re-election. Senator Richard G. Lugar, a Republican, easily won re-election to a sixth term. Steve Osborn, a Libertarian, opposed him.

Iowa
 Democrats elected a governor, won control of both houses of the state legislature and, in a stunning upset, ousted Representative Jim Leach, a moderate Republican from Iowa City who had been in Congress for 30 years.
 It is the first time since 1964 that Democrats have controlled the governor's office and both houses of the legislature. 
 Mr. Leach voted against the war in Iraq, but that was not enough to secure victory in the Second District, which includes the University of Iowa. He was defeated by Dave Loebsack, a professor of politics and international relations at Cornell College in Mount Vernon.
 Mr. Loebsack framed the race as a referendum on Bush administration policies. Democrats described Mr. Leach as an ''enabler'' for more conservative Republicans.
 In some ways, Mr. Leach said, ''This is the happiest day of my life.'' He said he felt ''as if a burden has been lifted.''
 Chet Culver, the Democratic candidate for governor, defeated Representative Jim Nussle, a Republican who went to Congress as an insurgent in 1991 but became a reliable ally of party leaders. Mr. Nussle did not run for re-election to Congress so that he could concentrate on his campaign for governor.
 Democrats noted that the federal budget deficit increased in recent years while Mr. Nussle was chairman of the House Budget Committee. Mr. Culver, the son of former Senator John C. Culver, is the Iowa secretary of state. 
 In the contest for Mr. Nussle's seat in Congress, the Democratic candidate, Bruce L. Braley, a former president of the Iowa Trial Lawyers Association, defeated the Republican, Mike Whalen, who owns and operates hotels and restaurants.
 Mr. Braley, like Mr. Loebsack, campaigned against President Bush and the war in Iraq. Mr. Whalen said the war was ''the overwhelming issue.'' 
 Democrats will have at least 29 seats in the 50-member State Senate and at least 54 of the 100 House seats.

Kansas
 Gov. Kathleen Sebelius has what so many of her fellow Democrats want: popularity with moderate and conservative voters in a deep red state. And as she cruised to re-election to her second term, that popularity prompted talk of her potential to be one of the party's national stars.
 Democrats had a good year in Kansas, largely because they wooed Republicans. Paul Morrison, until recently a Republican, ran for attorney general as a Democrat and easily unseated Phill Kline, the incumbent who had been criticized for linking his campaign operation to evangelical churches. A former Republican state party chairman, Mark Parkinson, changed sides this year and was elected lieutenant governor.
 A Republican member of Congress, Jim Ryun, the former Olympic distance runner, lost his seat to a Democrat, Nancy Boyda.
 Republicans retained control of the state Board of Education, but critics of teaching evolution lost their majority.

Michigan
 Democrats took the State House for the first time in eight years, retained control over the governor's mansion and won other key races, giving the party significant control over political apparatus in the state.
 And the passage of a measure that prohibits public institutions from considering race and sex in public education, employment and contracting set the stage for litigation and similar proposals in other states.
 Economic issues like job losses in the auto industry served as an undercurrent to the elections, but the top Democratic Party official in the state said the party did a good job emphasizing local issues such as health insurance, the liability of drug companies in defective product cases, and importation of trash from Canada.
 ''Economic issues were important in the House races, but not overwhelming,'' said Mark Brewer, chairman of the state's Democratic Party. 
 In the State Senate, the Democrats were still awaiting final vote tallies on several races to see whether they would take control of that chamber.
 And as supporters of the anti-affirmative-action ballot initiative celebrated and considered the national implications of their victory, officials at the University of Michigan said they would fight the constitutional amendment in court.
 Michigan's proposal is similar to a measure approved by California voters in 1996. The Michigan campaign was backed by Ward Connerly, a former University of California regent and a wealthy black Republican from Sacramento, and Jennifer Gratz, a white woman placed on a waiting list by the University of Michigan 11 years ago.
 In other top races, Gov. Jennifer Granholm defeated the Republican candidate, Dick DeVos, and Senator Debbie Stabenow bested Michael Bouchard, a Republican.

Missouri
 Missouri has a well-earned history as a bellwether state, voting for the presidential victor every time but one since 1904. On Tuesday, Missourians seemed to reflect the national mood again, handing a Senate seat to the Democratic state auditor, Claire C. McCaskill, in one of the country's most closely watched races.
 Ms. McCaskill ousted the Republican incumbent, Jim Talent, in a race lately dominated by debate over a measure to protect stem cell research, which Ms. McCaskill supported and Mr. Talent opposed, and which passed by the same 2-point margin that Ms. McCaskill held over her opponent.
 The amendment blocks state and local governments from banning any federally permitted stem-cell research effort, including the embryonic cloning opposed by conservative Christians. A late-October advertisement featuring the actor Michael J. Fox, who has Parkinson's disease, praising Ms. McCaskill as he swayed before the camera, attracted national attention -- and the opprobrium of the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh, who accused Mr. Fox of exaggerating his symptoms.
 According to exit polls, evangelical and born-again Christians voted overwhelmingly for Mr. Talent, but Ms. McCaskill performed strongly in the traditional Republican rural strongholds while beating Mr. Talent soundly in the cities.
 As in much of the country, the election was also in part a referendum on Iraq and the president. Fully 90 percent of McCaskill voters said in exit polls that the war was an important factor in their vote, and more than 60 percent said they voted for her to express disapproval of President Bush.
 Missourians voted to increase the minimum wage to $6.50 an hour from the federal level of $5.15. They rejected a proposal to increase the cigarette tax. 

SENATE
98% reporting
McCaskill: 1,028,920 49%
Talent: 987,383 47%

Minnesota
 In one of the most closely watched races for governor in the nation, Gov. Tim Pawlenty eked out a victory over Mike Hatch, a Democrat. Mr. Pawlenty won by a percentage point, earning 46.7 percent of the vote to 45.7 percent for Mr. Hatch. 
 In the final weeks of the campaign, Mr. Pawlenty was behind in statewide polls, a marked departure from his status as an up-and-coming star of the Republican Party, and suffered from rising local opposition to the war in Iraq. Still, holding onto his seat may have a rejuvenating effect on Mr. Pawlenty's national status in the wake of widespread Republican losses in other states.
 But the state had notable Democratic triumphs as well. In the Senate race to fill the seat vacated by Mark Dayton, a Democrat, Amy Klobuchar, a Democrat and the county attorney in Hennepin County, became the first woman elected to the Senate in Minnesota history. In a landslide victory, Ms. Klobuchar captured 58 percent of the vote to defeat Representative Mark Kennedy, a Republican who had to struggle to keep his House seat in 2004. 
 Representative Gil Gutknecht, a six-term Republican, lost his seat to Tim Walz, a teacher and former member of the National Guard, 52 percent to 47 percent.

Nebraska
 Nebraska appeared largely untouched by the Democratic wave that swept over many other states.
 The state's Congressional delegation will continue to have just one Democrat, Senator Ben Nelson, who easily won a second term by defeating Pete Ricketts, the Republican. But Mr. Nelson, a former governor and state insurance director, prides himself on being able to work with President Bush and other Republicans.
 State Senator Adrian Smith, a 35-year-old Republican, won an open seat in the conservative Third District, which Mr. Bush carried with three-fourths of the vote in 2004. Mr. Smith said he was inspired to run for public office by President Ronald Reagan, whom he has admired since the fourth grade. 
 Mr. Smith defeated Scott Kleeb, a Yale-educated rancher who was endorsed by the conservative Omaha World-Herald, the state's largest newspaper. The seat has been held for six years by Representative Tom Osborne, a former football coach for the Nebraska Cornhuskers who made an unsuccessful bid for the Republican nomination for governor.
 Gov. Dave Heineman, who won the Republican primary, sailed to victory in the general election, defeating his Democratic challenger, David Hahn, a political newcomer. Mr. Heineman, a former lieutenant governor, became chief executive in January 2005, after Mr. Bush chose Gov. Mike Johanns to be secretary of agriculture.

North Dakota
 There may be no state whose voting habits are harder to pin down. North Dakotans vote heavily Republican for president and state offices, yet for many years they have sent only Democrats to Congress.
 Senator Kent Conrad and the state's only representative, Earl Pomeroy, both won re-election by roughly two to one over little-known challengers, Dwight Grotberg and Matt Mechtel. That was a marked change for Mr. Pomeroy, who has had some close races. 
 Voters also showed their conservative side in approving a constitutional amendment limiting state and local governments' power to seize private property to transfer it to another private owner for economic development. North Dakota was one of several states with such measures on the ballot.

100% reporting
Conrad: 149,317 68.8%

Pomeroy: 142,121 65.6%
Mechtel: 74,364 34.4%

Ohio
 Voters brought the Republicans' monopoly over Ohio politics to a dramatic end.
 Ted Strickland, the Democratic candidate for governor, garnered more than 60 percent of the votes in defeating his Republican rival, J. Kenneth Blackwell. Sherrod Brown, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, won almost 56 percent of votes in defeating the incumbent, Senator Mike DeWine. And Democratic candidates for attorney general, secretary of state and other statewide offices also won with significantly more than 50 percent of the votes.
 Still, Democrats appeared to have gained only one seat in Congress, winning six of Ohio's 18 Congressional seats. Two races in which Republicans led by narrow margins, in the suburbs of Columbus and Cincinnati, had not yet been called yesterday.
 Driving the Democratic victories were the voters' anger with corruption in government, job losses in Ohio's crumbling industrial economy, the war in Iraq and President Bush, voters said in interviews after they cast ballots. About 6 of every 10 voters called Ohio's economy not so good or poor and said they disapproved of Mr. Bush's job performance and of the war in Iraq, according to exit polls.
 Those percentages, which matched Mr. Strickland's and Mr. Brown's margins of victory, raised the question: If as many as 60 percent of Ohio voters statewide cast ballots for Democratic candidates for governor and for the Senate, why did Democrats apparently win only 33 percent of the Congressional seats? 
 ''It's the gerrymander effect,'' said Richard Gunther, a political science professor at Ohio State University. Republicans in control of the Ohio legislature had drawn the state's congressional districts in ways that concentrate Democratic voters into some districts, thereby wasting some of their votes, while diluting Democratic votes in cities like Columbus, where the vote-rich metropolitan area is splintered into three districts that extend deeply into mostly Republican rural counties, Mr. Gunther said.
 Tuesday's victories in the races for governor and for secretary of state will give Democrats a majority on the board charged with drawing the boundaries of state legislative districts. But the power to draw Congressional boundaries rests with the legislature, both houses of which are still controlled by Republicans.
 Four candidates who support the teaching of evolution in public schools either retained or won seats on the Ohio Board of Education in all four races in which the teaching of evolution was an issue. In one of the most-watched races, Tom Sawyer, a former Democratic Congressman and mayor of Akron, defeated Deborah Owens Fink, a marketing professor at the University of Akron. Scientists at Ohio State University, Case Western Reserve University and elsewhere recruited Mr. Sawyer to challenge Dr. Owens Fink and, in an unusual move, most of the Case Western Reserve faculty signed a letter endorsing Mr. Sawyer's candidacy. Dr. Owens Fink's says children should be taught to think critically about evolution, although she no longer advocates the teaching of intelligent design. Intelligent design is an ideological cousin of creationism.

SENATE
100% reporting
Brown: 2,133,690 55.9%
DeWine: 1,680,999 44.1%

GOVERNOR
100% reporting
Strickland: 2,307,420 60.4%
Blackwell: 1,406,792 36.8%

South Dakota
 A majority of voters rejected a broad ban on abortion put to South Dakotans by state lawmakers, halting an effort, at least for now, to prompt the Supreme Court to reconsider the Roe v. Wade decision.
 Abortion-rights advocates hailed the 56 percent to 44 percent vote as a reminder that most Americans support women's right to choose, but supporters of the ban were undeterred, saying they had failed to communicate their message effectively.
 ''This is a wake-up call to lawmakers in other states that America's pro-choice majority will not allow an assault on Roe v. Wade to go unanswered,'' Nancy Keenan, the president of Naral Pro-Choice America, said in a statement.
 Officials at the South Dakota group Vote Yes for Life said they were heartened by support for the measure. The group said some voters might have been confused by the measure's wording on the ballot, and others might have been turned off by anti-abortion advocates not affiliated with the campaign who used images of dead fetuses.
 ''Our biggest enemy was the outside groups that came in,'' Leslee Unruh, who leads Vote Yes for Life, said in a telephone interview yesterday. ''We begged them to stay out, but they wouldn't stay out.''
 There were no significant upsets in statewide races. Gov. Michael Rounds, a Republican, and Representative Stephanie Herseth, a Democrat, easily won re-election.

Wisconsin
 A barely blue state in 2004, Wisconsin stayed Democratic again on Tuesday. Gov. Jim Doyle narrowly escaped with a re-election victory over his Republican challenger, Representative Mark Green, a four-term member of the House.
 The race was one of the most heated and divisive in decades, as candidates sparred over stem cells, the economy and taxes.
 Senator Herb Kohl, a widely popular Democrat, handily recaptured his seat for a fourth term, defeating Robert Lorge, a Republican. 
 The more revealing outcomes of the election were the results of two ballot initiatives, both indicating a rising tide of conservatism in a state that once prided itself as the home of political creativity and progressive thought under Robert M. La Follette.
 Wisconsin voters approved a measure to amend the state Constitution to prohibit same-sex unions, an initiative with wording so ambiguous that some experts have expressed concern that it could also apply to heterosexual cohabitation, said David Canon, a professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. 
 Another initiative represented a shift in opinion on the death penalty, which was abolished in Wisconsin in 1853.
 In a nonbinding state referendum, the majority of voters said they approved the reinstatement of the death penalty. Mr. Doyle has promised to veto a death penalty bill if it is passed by the State Legislature.
 Mr. Doyle will enter his second term with a host of issues to confront, including a stagnant economy, a rapid loss of manufacturing jobs and a rising budget deficit.

SENATE
100% reporting
Kohl: 1,436,623 67.4%
Lorge: 629,127 29.5%

GOVERNOR
100% reporting
Doyle: 1,136,726 52.8%
Green: 976,275 45.3%

A tally with a brief report about Iowa in the State by State election roundup on Thursday erroneously showed an identical vote count for both candidates in the Second Congressional District. Representative Jim Leach, the Republican incumbent, received 101,386 votes, not 107,097. His Democratic opponent, Dave Loebsack, received 107,097 votes.

HEADLINE: Setting Out Into the Wilderness With Only a Knife

BYLINE: By JONATHAN GREEN

 BODY:
ON a brisk morning in October, Lee Posner, a stout New York orthopedic devices salesman, drove to a remote spot in the northern Arizona mountains, removed his glasses, unclipped his cellphone and placed them in the glove box. Then, with a deep sigh, he stepped into the cougar-infested wilderness with nothing more than a sharp knife. 
 His face was a mask of apprehension as he struck out through the thick Ponderosa pines. ''My survival will come down to this,'' he said, patting the knife (a Swedish Mora knife with a four-inch blade) at his waist as he negotiated some thick sagebrush. ''The blade will decide.''
Mr. Posner was one of three people taking a two-day course led by Tony Nestor of Ancient Pathways, an Arizona outdoor survival school that teaches survival using only primitive technology. Participants are allowed to take only a knife, the clothes they arrive in and a tiny survival kit containing parachute cord, a fire sparker and a water bottle. Tent, sleeping bag, G.P.S., camping mattress and, more important, food, are all forbidden. The idea is to learn how to survive if a day hike goes wrong. 
 Shaded under the greasy brim of a worn bush hat, Mr. Nestor hiked a few steps behind the group. ''We belong out here,'' he said, scrambling up mossy rocks with the agility of a mountain goat. ''It's our birthright. We've had a spear in our hands a lot longer than we've had a laptop. If you have knowledge, all you need out here is a knife.'' 
 Mr. Nestor, a soft-spoken man with a phlegmatic demeanor and a natural, calorie-saving economy of movement, has made it his life's work to understand how to survive in the wild with nothing. From the age of 17 he has wandered the country spending years with mountain men, Indians and outdoor survivalists to learn his craft. Proudly mounted on the living room wall of his solar-powered house in Flagstaff are the sticks he used the first time he started a fire ''in the old way.'' 
 He has become such an authority on outdoor survival, particularly desert survival, that he has taught it to Hopi and Navajo students, as well as to the Army's Special Forces before their deployment to Iraq and Afghanistan. He also trains prospective contestants on the television reality show ''Survivor'' who are eager to gain an edge.
 Mostly, though, he teaches a growing band of people intrigued with primitive technology. ''With Y2K and then 9/11, the numbers interested in this have exploded,'' Mr. Nestor said. ''A lot of people want to be less reliant, particularly after Hurricane Katrina. People want to know how to survive when the shelves at the grocery store are not filled with food and the government is not around to supply water.'' A significant number of his students are women.
 Becoming a real weekend Rambo appeals on a number of different levels. ''Modern hiking inventions are great,'' Mr. Posner said. ''But Gore-Tex is not going to find me water if I am stranded. I was a huge fan of Tarzan growing up, and I have always been fascinated with the idea of living in the wild with only a knife.''
 Elliot Spaulding, 23, an undergraduate at Northern Arizona University, agreed. ''I'm more interested in how my ancestors used to live,'' he said. ''I want to sleep in a shelter that I have made myself, in front of a fire that I have lit myself with nothing more than sticks.''
 The kind of course Mr. Spaulding and Mr. Posner were taking (this reporter was the third student) does have very real dangers. Last July, Dave Buschow, 29, a security operative from River Vale, N.J., died in Utah while taking part in a 28-day survival course run by the Boulder Outdoor Survival School. 
 After an hour of hiking up and down mountains and canyons at 7,000 feet, Mr. Nestor led the group to a clearing in the dense pine woods. ''Shelter is one of the first thing you need to take care of, whether you are roasting in the desert or freezing in sub-zero degrees,'' he said. 
 He instructed his students on how to make a primitive shelter called a wickiup. We lashed the ends of two 12-foot logs to the trunk of a tree with a half-hitch at roughly waist height, forming a steeple. We then hacked and laid branches along the sides and dropped pine needles over the top to seal it. We were left with a wigwam shape big enough for two people, along with a pie-shaped space at the front where we would build our fire pit. We then littered the floor inside with pine needles. ''You have to have something between you and the ground,'' Mr. Nestor said. ''Otherwise the ground will suck the 98.6 degrees of temperature right out of your body.'' 
 The next imperative was the hunt for water and food. We hiked deep into a tree-lined canyon, where the rocks at the bottom held rust-brown rainwater. The oasis was used as a waterhole by local animals. Mr. Nestor pointed out footprints. ''Those three-lobe prints would indicate a cougar,'' he said. Mr. Posner filled his water bottle with a wary eye on the canyon's rocky outcrops. 
 Sinewy stalks of wild onions protruded from the boggy ground around the waterhole. Mr. Nestor instructed the group to dig out the marble-size onions using our blades. It took a good hour of hard labor to collect even a cupful.
 MR. NESTOR regarded everything in the outdoors as having a utilitarian purpose. Don't have a toothbrush for the night? Cut a fresh twig from an oak tree and scrape your teeth with it; the tannin acts as a natural toothpaste. Don't have rope? Use the fibrous leaves of the yucca plant and braid them into a line which is strong enough to lash shelters or even to use as mountaineering rope. 
 We foraged a few wild cranberries and spent a further hour collecting acorns in our bandanas. But soon hunger, a chilling drop in temperature and darkness descended on the group. Mr. Nestor could tell how many hours of daylight were left by measuring how many fists there were between the sun and the horizon. ''We have an hour to get back to camp to light a fire,'' he said.
 Back at camp, we whittled wood to make fire-making implements. A bow drill consisted of a flexible piece of wood bent into a bow shape with some cord, a spindle made from yucca stalk and a flat piece of wood known as a fireboard. Mr. Spaulding pulled the bow back and forth, with a jerky, forceful momentum, spinning the spindle in the fireboard and producing a fine, hot dust. The friction eventually produced a little billowing cloud of smoke and then a few licks of flame in the withering light, just as the sun sank below a tree-lined ridge. The dust was used to light pitch from a pine tree. A blanket of complete darkness descended just as the fire gathered a roaring life of its own. ''Natural fire that I made myself,'' Mr. Spaulding said, grinning with his accomplishment.
 The group, ravenous with hunger, began the laborious process of shelling acorns, which were dropped into a rusty can we had found. Then we boiled up an acorn-and-wild-onion broth and devoured it ravenously. But we were all still hungry. Despite laboring for much of the day collecting onions and acorns we still couldn't fill our bellies.
 ''I'm so hungry I could eat a squirrel,'' Mr. Posner said morosely. Mr. Nestor explained that in an emergency situation hunting could burn up more calories, especially when there was a chance of not actually catching anything. 
 Mr. Nestor has regularly dined on pack rats, mice and squirrels on his long sojourns in the wild. ''When it's winter and there is no food on the ground, you have to eat that to survive,'' he said, shadows cast by the campfire flickering over his face. ''You can't be squeamish about it. It's a good thing our ancestors weren't or we wouldn't be here today. Mice are too small to skin, so you just throw them on the fire and eat them whole. Rats you throw on for 30 seconds to burn off bubonic plague, lice and parasites and then skin them. If you're really hungry you just eat them straight down.'' 
 The long night stretched out ahead of us. The temperature dropped to 36 degrees. The soaring darkness of the woods enclosed as the needling cold stabbed into our clothing. We lay on our beds of prickly pine needles, sticking some into our clothes for extra insulation. We fed the fire to stay warm. The smoke from the fire pit billowed into our eyes, turning them bloodshot and sooty. We either roasted in the shelter or froze when we fell asleep and the fire died. 
 A gray dawn woke us early. Despite lack of sleep and a gnawing hunger with little food for 24 hours, there was a sense of pride we had survived the night. ''There are students and advanced students,'' Mr. Nestor said, ''but no masters when it comes to outdoor survival.''
 Our trip was only a taste, but it demonstrated the brutality of life without easily accessible food, heat, light and all the other features of modern living that we take for granted. ''It's about a positive mental attitude and knowledge of the jungle,'' Mr. Posner said. ''Just like Tarzan had.''
 Mr. Nestor demonstrated signaling with a mirror to use in an emergency. The flash can be seen as far as 105 miles away by rescue workers. And with that lesson we made our escape from the wilderness. 
 Mr. Posner tucked his knife securely into the waistband of his pants and hiked back to civilization. ''Right,'' he said, safely back at his car. ''Where's a McDonald's? I want a quarter-pounder with cheese.''

READY FOR ANYTHING

Relying on a Blade And Your Wits

FOR those who like the idea of learning to be real weekend Tarzans and Rambos, there are a number of instructors around the country who teach knife-only survival courses:

ARIZONA -- Ancient Pathways (928-526-2552; www.apathways.com) offers a full range of courses from knife-only, starting at $275, up to a nine-week bushcraft course for $4,800.

MONTANA -- At the Wilderness Arts Institute (406-660-2204; www.wilderness-arts.com), David Cronenwett offers one- and five-day survival courses in the northern Rockies for around $100 a person a day.

NEW HAMPSHIRE -- Tim Smith of the Jack Mountain Bushcraft and Guide Service(603-569-6150; www.jackmtn.com) offers various bushcraft and survival outings for $125 a day or $250 for a two-day course.
