SECTION: Section F; Column 3; Giving; GIVING CIRCLES; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: Putting Their Heads Together, Then Their Cash

BYLINE: By CHRISTIAN L. WRIGHT

 BODY:
THEY started getting together on Thursday nights for a glass of wine about 10 years ago, after one woman's husband died.
 They were just a group of old friends in Oshkosh, Wis., who saw one another through children's weddings, the births of grandchildren and rounds of cancer treatment.
 ''We'd support each other, as women do, through these joys and challenges,'' said Sue Ebling, 58. 
 Then, on a Thursday in 2002, one woman suggested they start a charitable fund. And their giving circle was born. Each of the 12 women in the Wine Ladies Fund agreed to give $25 twice a year. ''Twenty-five dollars doesn't mean very much,'' said Ms. Ebling, the chairwoman of the circle, ''but when pooled together, it makes a huge impact.''
 It's not just the pooling together. The giving circle's money is managed by the Women's Fund of the Oshkosh Area Community Foundation, which invests a portion. So part of each donation is put to work immediately while the rest grows. 
 In the Wine Ladies' case, the fund grows faster than it would based on $25 gifts: some members contribute large sums, and people outside the group make gifts as well. 
 The nonprofit world calls it leveraging philanthropy. 
 A giving circle is a bit like a book club, a sewing bee or those investment groups for church members who pool resources and buy stock. A giving circle can be big or small and vary in demographics, interests and resources. The Wine Ladies Fund in Oshkosh focuses on adolescent girls in the area. Each member of the circle has a vote on which grants to make. In 2005, the group gave $5,000, earmarked for a girls' nutrition program in the Boys and Girls Club. 
 ''Probably people wouldn't bother to make an individual donation,'' said Ms. Ebling. But in the giving circle, she said, ''There's a camaraderie and a group motivation to do good, especially for those of us in small communities without deep pockets.'' 
 The National Philanthropic Trust says that 89 percent of American households make charitable contributions each year. The gifts may be piecemeal: $25 to save the leatherback turtle and $50 to a college alumni fund, or maybe a larger pledge to be paid over years to fight world hunger or help the environment.
 Giving circles join like-minded people across socioeconomic lines. Some of the circles are informal, with each member writing a check to the chosen charity or cause. Others are more organized, with bank accounts and tax advisers. Fields of interest include children, women, education, economic development, human services, the arts, gay and lesbian issues and natural and historic preservation.
 More formal groups include the Full Circle Fund in San Francisco, which calls itself an engaged philanthropic organization. The fund was started six years ago by Josh Becker. At the time, Mr. Becker was busy with his job at a venture capital firm, but kept thinking about education and housing, the issues that had always been important to him. He wanted to have an impact, and so did a lot of his colleagues. 
 They decided to harness their ''intellectual, financial, social and political capital'' as the group's mission states, to tackle the community's most pressing problems and find solutions.
 The group of 10 has grown to 75. The members, many of whom work in finance or technology, commit both time and money in three areas: housing, technology and education. 
 ''We use all the tools in the toolbox to create social change,'' said Mr. Becker, 37, the fund's chairman. ''We actively look for ways to change policy.''
 Jeff Camp, chairman of the education committee of the fund, said: ''My commitment was $5,000. But the time commitment in some ways is more challenging. Do we do painting days? No, that's not the kind of organization we are.'' 
 Instead, they help with business plans (as they did for the Leadership High School, a small charter school in San Francisco) and act as management consultants (as they did for an expansion at the New Teacher Center at the University of California, Santa Cruz). Since it began in 2000, the Full Circle Fund has raised about $2.5 million and has made about 20 grants.
 The giving circle model is particularly popular among women, said Anne Mosle, president of the eight-year-old Washington Area Women's Foundation, which has generated two such circles. ''Historically, we're the volunteers and have done the bake sales,'' she said. ''We're building a pipeline of women philanthropists to reclaim that power.'' 
 Her foundation has grown 50 percent in the last five years. In 2000, $40,000 went into the community. In 2005, the foundation and the giving circles gave more than $1 million in grants. 
 Barbara Strom Thompson is a co-chairwoman of the Rainmakers Giving Circle, one of two circles that operate under the umbrella of the Washington foundation. The Rainmakers are 20 women, ''from stay-at-home moms to doctors,'' each of whom pledges $5,000 over two years, Ms. Thompson said. ''All of us could give checks on our own,'' she said. ''But together we can be more strategic and more public about it.'' 
 One grant made by the Rainmakers in 2005 was $10,000 to a reading program at the Middle School for Girls in Anacostia, a poor neighborhood in southeast Washington. 
 There is a waiting list for the Rainmakers and the other giving circle that grew from the foundation, the African-American Giving Circle, Ms. Mosle said. In three years, the Washington Area Women's Foundation may have eight more circles up and running, she said. 
 ''There's a buzz in the room when people come together and connect through their sense of community,'' Ms. Mosle said. ''People are looking to be part of something bigger than themselves.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: GATHERING -- Betsy Ganther, top left, and Phyllis Leach, right, belong to the Wine Ladies Fund in Oshkosh, Wis. HEADLINE: Aiding the Schools That Gave Them a Chance

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
NOTHING succeeds like success, as the saying goes, and nowhere is that more evident than at the nation's richest universities and colleges. Even as the coffers at Harvard, Yale and other prestigious institutions overflow, money continues to pour in, especially from their driven Type-A alumni.
 Last March, for example, Columbia University announced a $200 million gift -- its largest single donation -- from Dawn M. Greene and the Jerome L. Greene Foundation. The money will establish a neuroscience center in honor of Mr. Greene, a former lawyer and real estate investor in New York who died in 1999. In August, Philip H. Knight, the founder of Nike, promised $105 million for a new business school campus at Stanford, a university with an endowment of $15 billion.
And Princeton University's alumni have pledged more than $40 million to the school's annual giving campaign this year, a record there. At last count, Princeton's endowment stood at $12.7 billion.
 With so much money going to A-list institutions, how are lesser-known universities competing? Some of them have stayed in the game by tapping into self-made alumni who remember the schools that gave them their chance. 
 Consider Syracuse University's association with Martin J. Whitman, a 1949 graduate who is an unusually successful investor and mutual fund manager in New York. Mr. Whitman, 82, oversees Third Avenue Funds, a family of mutual funds that has beaten the market averages handily over the years. 
 Syracuse University, Mr. Whitman said, was the only school that would accept him as an undergraduate. Although he also attended Princeton at the graduate level, Mr. Whitman has focused much of his giving on Syracuse, providing the money for the Martin J. Whitman School of Management as well as scholarships for minority students who are not athletes. 
 Mr. Whitman declined to say how much he has given to his alma mater over the years, but he explained why he chose Syracuse. ''During the G.I. bulge, it wasn't easy to get in places,'' Mr. Whitman recalled. ''It was the only place that would take me.'' The son of a women's milliner, he grew up in the Bronx, one of three children in a lower-middle-class family, he said.
 His decision to pay for a business school arose out of Mr. Whitman's belief that most universities' finance programs have little to do with the real world. ''They don't have a clue about 90 percent of what goes on in the financial community,'' he said.
 Tom Walsh, senior vice president for institutional advancement at Syracuse University, said that university officials understood that Mr. Whitman was a teacher at heart and appealed to him that way. ''We began by putting him in the classroom,'' Mr. Walsh said. ''Not too long after that, Marty did a skillful analysis of what needed to happen to increase the quality of the a school.'' The result, Mr. Walsh said, was a jump in Syracuse's ranking among the nation's universities. 
 Baruch College, one of the 11 senior colleges of the City University of New York, has also had success attracting money from grateful alumni, a process that was begun in earnest during the late 1990s after state financing for the institution began to decline. Bernard M. Baruch, the Depression-era financier and presidential adviser, endowed Baruch College with $9 million in 1953. But by 1998, the college's endowment had barely budged. 
 Now, however, the endowment stands at $100 million, thanks to a throng of alumni who appreciate the education they received at Baruch. Their appreciation rises, some have told college officials, as they write tuition checks for their children to attend Ivy League colleges. 
 ''Most of the donors are not shy about saying that they may have gone on to law degrees at Harvard and other degrees at Columbia, but they give back to Baruch because without Baruch they would not have gone on at all,'' said Kathleen M. Waldron, Baruch's president. ''These are primarily men and some women who came from the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn, who took the subway to college who could only go to Baruch because it was free.'' 
 One major donor is Lawrence Zicklin, a former chairman of Neuberger Berman, the money management firm that is a subsidiary of Lehman Brothers. A Baruch graduate who wanted to give back to the institution that gave him his start, Mr. Zicklin donated $18 million in 1998 to build the Zicklin School of Business at Baruch. His and other alumni donations go to supplement professors' salaries so that the institution can compete with richer universities. 
 ''I had put aside money all the years I was working because I knew I wanted to make a gift to an educational institution,'' Mr. Zicklin said. ''I was indebted to City University. No Baruch, no Zicklin, I always say. Everything became possible because of Baruch.'' 
 Like many Baruch students, Mr. Zicklin, 70, came from a family of modest means. He grew up in Brooklyn, where his father, an immigrant from Eastern Europe, owned a candy store. He went to public schools, then Baruch and on to receive his master's in business administration from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. 
 But he never forgot his undergraduate experience. ''You learn how to be hungry at Baruch,'' he said. ''You learn how to scratch.''
 The University of Massachusetts has also benefited from the achievements of its striving alumni. Like Baruch, it has coped with decreasing state financing, which recently accounted for just 26 percent of the university's operating budget. 
 Eugene M. Isenberg, chief executive of Nabors Industries, an oil services business, has given approximately $9 million to the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, the school that he said helped him overcome a hardscrabble youth. 
 Mr. Isenberg, 76, the son of an immigrant father, grew up in Chelsea, Mass., a town that filed for bankruptcy after the Depression. His family was lower-middle class, but his father dissuaded him from joining the Navy right after high school and pushed him toward college instead. At the last minute, Mr. Isenberg applied to UMass to learn a trade, he said.
 Although Mr. Isenberg went on to earn a master's degree in economics from Princeton, he decided against donating money there. ''I thought, Where could a buck go the farthest, where can you get the best productivity out of a contribution?'' he said. ''Princeton didn't need it. I concluded UMass Amherst was the place.'' 
 He and his wife, Ronnie have established the Isenberg School of Management at UMass and endowed three professorships there -- one in integrative studies at the business school, another in environmental science and a third in engineering. The couple continue to provide the university with $70,000 in scholarship money every year. 
 ''There are people out there who remember their roots and recognize the value of education in their own careers,'' Mr. Isenberg said. ''Education is key to the kingdom in America. I would like to give other people the opportunity I've had.''

HEADLINE: Vintage Fashions Lure Shoppers and Charities Alike

BYLINE: By SUSAN SAITER

 BODY:
JENNIFER SCHNEIDER, a lawyer in Washington, flies to Seattle each November to celebrate her birthday with a shopping spree. She and her sister stake out turf on the sidewalk at 5 a.m. and rev up on coffee and doughnuts as they strategize, making sure their cellphones work so they can alert each other to bargains once they are in the store.
 But they are not waiting for first dibs on designer creations; they are there for the clothing at the Seattle Goodwill Thrift Shop's one-day Glitter Sale. 
 The Schneider sisters dress in leotards, even if it means shivering in the rain, as it did last year, so that they can try on clothes without having to go to a dressing room. ''Once we get inside, we know it is definitely worth it,'' Ms. Schneider said. 
 Last year, they shopped all day and spent about $750. ''I got a ton of stuff, including a pair of Gucci shoes for $14,'' Ms. Schneider said. ''And mostly, I like shopping at a store that I know helps people out with job training.'' 
 The Glitter Sale itself was a record-setting success, bringing in $50,000 for Goodwill Industries, which provides job training and employment services, said Betsy McFeely, a spokeswoman.
 Ms. Schneider and Goodwill Industries represent the win-win phenomenon of trendy customers and nonprofit vintage stores. Clothing sales get most of the credit for the roughly 10 percent annual increase in revenue for the last 10 years at Goodwill's 2,078 shops around the United States, said Christine Nyirjesy Bragale, spokeswoman for Goodwill Industries International. While resale shops are usually in the furniture business, apparel is the biggest seller. 
 ''Clothing has become the dominant sales item because furniture is harder to pick up,'' said Major Paul Cranford, administrator for the Salvation Army Manhattan Adult Rehabilitation Center.
 The Salvation Army thrift shops provide on-the-job training for many who would not get the chance in the private sector. ''Most of the people we help have alcohol or drug issues,'' he said. ''Some are from prisons or broken homes.''
 The National Association of Resale and Thrift Shops reported that there were more than 25,000 resale, consignment and thrift shops in the United States, and that the industry was experiencing a growth of about 5 percent a year. 
 The association estimated that 16 to 18 percent of Americans shop in thrift stores, compared with about 11 percent who go to outlets and about 20 percent who shop in clothing or department stores. Last year, Goodwill sales totaled $1.64 billion. 
 Goodwill is not alone in benefiting from the popularity of vintage clothing. Salvation Army thrift shops in the New York metropolitan area, for example, had a 5 percent increase in profits last year, said Major Dennis Gensler, a spokesman.
 ''Goodwill is my favorite place on earth,'' said Rose Komesar, a student at Wesleyan University in Middleton, Conn. ''You're benefiting a charity, you're recycling.'' she said. ''Some students do their own tailoring of Goodwill clothes using old sewing machines they bought at Goodwill.'' Ms. Komesar added that she also donates clothes to Goodwill.
 Ricky Becker, manager of the Vintage Thrift Shop near Gramercy Park in Manhattan, said that it was not unusual, nor did it hurt business, when celebrities like Paul McCartney and Chloe Sevigny browsed. 
 ''But we have students, we have neighborhood people -- including a regular who is a 96-year-old lady in the neighborhood -- and we have lots of Japanese tourists,'' Mr. Becker said. ''I have people who come in here every single day that we're open. The men's stuff has just taken off.'' 
 The shop benefits the United Jewish Council of the East Side. ''Five years ago,'' said Toni Boston, the store supervisor, ''I went through their job training program that is supposed to help unemployed women prepare for the real world. It's opened a lot of doors for me. I have become knowledgeable about antiques and designer clothing.'' 
 The nine Angel View Thrift Stores in Palm Springs, Calif., which provide therapeutic services to disabled children, have had double-digit increases in sales over the past 10 years, said Tracy Powers, general manager of the stores. He said that last year, the stores' net donation to their mission doubled because of a change in strategy. In the past, he said, they had concentrated their advertising on getting customers. More recently, they have focused on getting more people to donate goods. 
 ''The desert is tremendously wealthy,'' he said. ''People go away for the summer and want to have the house redecorated, and donate the entire contents of the house to us.'' 
 Major Cranford said that clothing donations to the Salvation Army have increased drastically over the past 20 years. Last year, he said, clothing sales were up by about $250,000. 
 Some shops become the darlings of fashion editors and well-known designers. Oscar de la Renta donates clothing and accessories to the City Opera Thrift Shop near Gramercy Park, the only thrift shop in New York City that supports the arts, said the store manager, Jay Thompson. ''We are very event-driven,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''We hold the good designer stuff -- Missoni, Chanel, Pucci, Diane Von Furstenberg and others -- for what we call Vintage Events twice a year.'' He also stages Diva Events, featuring new designer clothing donated from the garment district. 
 This year, the Diva and Vintage Events, each only three to four hours, raised more than $100,000 for the shop, Mr. Thompson said.
 The Spence-Chapin Thrift Shop on the Upper East Side, which benefits Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children, an adoption agency, also receives many designer vintage suits and handbags, said its manager, Tina Brivic. ''No matter what it looks like, if it's a Chanel suit, they'll buy it.'' 
 All this is not to say that donations to resale shops always keep up with demand. Or, as Lisa Barrow, manager of the Salvation Army thrift shop in Riverhead, N.Y., said, ''Vintage -- boom -- gone.''

HEADLINE: Wireless Technology To Bind an African Village

BYLINE: By MATT VILLANO

 BODY:
NEAR Fort Portal, Uganda, where modern resources are scarce and power outages occur daily, four remote villages are harnessing solar-powered computers, wireless networks and telephones to help farmers compete in the regional economy. The computer-and-telephone system, designed by the San Francisco nonprofit group Inveneo, also enables villagers to surf the Web, build databases, use e-mail and make phone calls over the Internet -- a big assist considering that the nearest land-line phone is two miles away.
 The impact has been immediate. Computer literacy among the 3,200 residents of the region is on the rise. The municipal governments have used the technology to organize records and cut back on paper files. 
 The local economy is benefiting as well, said Jane Nabwire, information technology officer of the project. In an e-mail message from Fort Portal, Ms. Nabwire said that farmers used the technology to call friends in larger cities and obtain market prices for produce before deciding whether the trek to town is worth it. ''The technology has brought services to people where they can access developmental information at any time,'' she wrote. ''In every possible way, it has made life for us easier.''
 To users in the United States who can pay bills online and answer e-mail on their cellphones, these technologies may not seem so vital. But in countries like Uganda, the gift of information and communications technology can change an entire area's perspective on the world.
 Many call this practice technophilanthropy, though the equipment involved is not always donated. Inveneo, although a nonprofit group, sells its technology to nongovernmental organizations, which supply it to areas in need. Another nonprofit, the AED-Satellife Center for Health Information and Technology in Watertown, Mass., gets financing through grants and gives the technology away.
 Jody Mahoney, senior director of international development at TechSoup, a nonprofit technology assistance agency in San Francisco, said that however the two groups arranged for payment for these projects, they shared a belief that technology can help developing nations help themselves.
 ''No one solution is going to work,'' she said. ''The best way to get technology into these nations is to create an ecosystem of partners that give people the tools they need to get things done.''
 Inveneo's efforts revolve around these partners. In 2003, two of its co-founders, Mark Summer and Robert Marsh, developed a wireless communications system for villagers in Laos while volunteering for a nongovernmental organization there.
 Last year, they took the technology to Uganda, teaming with ActionAid. Together, the two groups chose a town called Bukuuku for an economic development pilot program because the villagers were farmers who earned less than a dollar a day.
 Since then, the effort has expanded greatly, including the setup in the Fort Portal area. Mr. Summer, who now serves as Inveneo's chief executive, said that by the end of the year it would be supporting 18 projects in Uganda, Rwanda, Ghana, Mali and Guinea-Bissau.
 At the AED-Satellife Center, the focus is on medicine with two goals: to disseminate information to health workers all over the world and to give nations like Rwanda and Uganda the ability to use technology to revolutionize the way they keep medical records.
 Crucial to this effort is a network of hand-held computers. With the help of a special wireless access point, the hand-held devices transmit information about patients from field offices to regional ministries of health. 
 The network, much like computers from Inveneo, runs on solar and battery power, and is meant to replace the paper-based record-keeping that characterized so many of these countries for years. Andrew Sideman, AED-Satellife's director of development, said this information was important because it helped doctors decide how resources were allocated.
 ''The gathering of health information doesn't sound very exciting, but it's the basis for how decisions are made,'' he said, adding that the Satellife network also enables Web surfing and e-mail communication for villagers and doctors alike. ''In meeting this need, we hope to improve the overall health of this part of the world.''
 So far in Uganda, Satellife has accomplished that goal. For years, when pregnant women gave birth, doctors had 72 hours afterward to dispatch a messenger to pick up a refrigerated dose of Nevirapine, a drug that kills H.I.V. in newborns and is routinely administered.
 Today, under the new system, the doctors send out e-mail queries as the mother is about to give birth, so the drug is there when the baby is born. 
 Somebody has to pay for this kind of project, and in Satellife's case, the network is underwritten by grants, including $1 million from the International Development Aid Research Center, the Canadian government organization akin to the United States Agency for International Development.
 Inveneo, on the other hand, finances its projects by selling the technology to nongovernmental organizations and other parties for $2,000 each. Inveneo then reinvests these funds into the company by buying new technology and making more computers to distribute in other developing nations.
 Skeptics question how important these efforts are to nations where people are dying of starvation. But Ms. Mahoney, the director of TechSoup, disagrees.
 ''Technology can be a tool to save people's lives,'' she said. ''Anything that enables these people to share information is a step in the right direction.''

HEADLINE: A Scarred Region Mends, With Help From Many Friends

BYLINE: By JOHN SCHWARTZ

DATELINE: New Orleans 

 BODY:
WHEN Dave Kelly decided to head to New Orleans from his home in Clinton, N.J., to help rebuild this sodden city, it was a choice of the heart, not the head. ''My wife thought I was pretty nuts,'' he said. 
 But, he said, he thought that ''getting involved was more than writing a check, watching TV, wringing my hands and saying, 'this is horrible.' ''
 So last November, he took a week off from work, kissed his wife and two children goodbye, and showed up in New Orleans. He had called ahead to a relief organization, Samaritan's Purse, and it offered to put him to work gutting homes.
 It was back-wrenching, smelly work for Mr. Kelly, a stocky contract manager for AT&T. And yet, ''Three, four hours after I started working there,'' he said, ''I was thinking of how to get back.'' 
 By last month, he was on his third trip -- taking a group of friends from his church as a core team for Samaritan's Purse, which is headed by Franklin Graham, the son of the evangelist Billy Graham. 
 The devastation that Hurricanes Katrina and Rita spread across the Gulf Coast last year still hangs over much of New Orleans. Mary Croom-Fontenot, executive director of All Congregations Together, a coalition of houses of worship in New Orleans, said the devastation was still so widespread that volunteers would be needed for years to come. 
 ''Whatever it is we do, we have to nurture and carry along for 10 years, even 20 years,'' she said. ''That's what planners are telling us. There's not a quick fix.''
 Still, extraordinary disaster has brought forth an extraordinary response. Billions of dollars in contributions poured into the Red Cross and other charities from all over the world. Along with the dollars, however, hundreds of thousands of people arrived at the Gulf Coast to assist, too. 
 The way that they have all come together, unbidden, is striking. A seemingly chaotic process transforms streams of volunteers from around the nation into efficient squads of helpers. People find groups to work with, sign up and go. Though it acts more like a swarm than a hierarchy, the efforts are certainly different from the way that, say, the Corps of Engineers builds a levee. 
 And it works. Jim Pate, the executive director of the New Orleans Area Habitat for Humanity, said that the statistics were impressive, but the sight of all the people is more so. ''This has got to be the largest outpouring of volunteer support in history,'' he said.
 Many of the volunteers are young. Some 219,000 college students worked in the gulf from 500 institutions over the last year, said Robert T. Grimm, director of research and policy development at the Corporation for National and Community Service, the government's largest grant maker for volunteer efforts and the manager of AmeriCorps. More than 35,000 national service participants have given more than 1.6 million hours of hands-on help to survivors and evacuees of Hurricane Katrina, he said.
 But helping rebuild New Orleans is not just a young persons' pursuit. Professional groups that have come to the city as part of the tent pole of its economy -- conventions -- have found time to lend a hand. 
 About 1,000 librarians of the group of about 18,000 in for their annual convention in June took time to rebuild some of the city's damaged libraries. And several hundred workers from Avaya, a telecommunications company, took time during their annual convention to pitch in as well, said Louis J. D'Ambrosio, the company's chief executive. The group met at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center, which itself was restored from being a pit of horror and despair, and went to fix up a school.
 The convention appealed to the company on many levels, he said. Even those of the company's 4,000 visitors who would not lift a crowbar could make a contribution, he said, simply by coming to the city, putting money in the hands of local people and the government. ''It's purchases that are generating the tax dollars that the city needs,'' he said.
 Of course, sometimes visitors try to do a bit of celebrating and rebuilding. Mr. Pate of Habitat said the results were not pretty. ''Sometimes, when they've been out partying the night before,'' he said, ''we wish they wouldn't come out,'' he said, only half joking. 
 He spoke not long after dawn under a startlingly blue sky, watching more than 100 people streaming into a cleared lot that Habitat for Humanity uses as its staging ground for the cluster of houses nearby known as Musicians' Village. 
 Close by, young AmeriCorps volunteers in a rotation from Charleston, S.C., huddled in the morning chill. Not far from them stood participants in a Pfizer sales meeting who had taken a morning away from a conference. A bit farther away, a team from the American Logistics Association was readying itself for the labors ahead. And three buses of conventioneers from the insurance industry drove up. 
 Many in New Orleans have found the work of volunteers more useful than the efforts of government or business. Irving Johnson III, who is 47, said his family was helped by a number of charities after the storm -- including Samaritan's Purse, which cleaned out his home and his mother's in New Orleans. The volunteers, he said, sped him on the way to rebuilding his home while allowing him to keep his job as a photographer on the staff of Xavier University.
 ''They have been a lifesaver,'' he said. He found himself frustrated again and again by government and corporate bureaucracies. 
 ''Everything is a stumbling block,'' said his mother, Judith Johnson. ''Everybody tells you about e-mail. I say: 'I don't own a toothpick. What makes you think I have an e-mail address? I don't have a house address.' They say, 'Well, you can fax it to us.' And I say, 'On what?' And she says, 'Ma'am, you don't have a fax machine?' And I said, 'I don't even have a bed.' ''
 By comparison, Irving Johnson said, he was heartened by the ability of the charities to get things done. ''Somehow, on a lower budget with a lot less overhead,'' he said, ''the volunteers have gotten it right.''
 The distinction is not always clear. Large charities like the Red Cross, after all, have bureaucracies that rival the Pentagon's. The Red Cross raised $2 billion and mobilized some 235,000 volunteers to work across the region. But the group came under fire for being slow to gear up, especially when helping minority communities. The group recently announced a reorganization intended to address the problems Katrina revealed. 
 Even government officials say that the charitable organizations are filling a gap that government has not. 
 ''It would be the testimony of every person along the gulf that without the volunteer groups, we would not be where we are today,'' said Donald Powell, the federal coordinator for Gulf Coast rebuilding. 
 Government might help finance some faith-based organizations, he said, but ''Government doesn't necessarily hold hands or hug.'' Along with homes, the charitable groups ''fix the emotions and the soul.''
 The volunteers, using word of mouth and the Internet, find the group that fits them -- whether religious or secular, politically conservative or progressive. Although the faith-based groups have received much of the attention, groups like Common Ground come at the New Orleans disaster with a socially active sensibility. 
 It has drawn its own brand of more than 10,000 volunteers, who have gutted and cleaned more than 1,000 homes, but also run clinics and provided legal advice on allegations of abuse by the police. 
 ''Social justice activists and those with a progressive consciousness were drawn to us,'' said Lisa Fithian, a coordinator for the group. In the days after the storm, she said, ''they saw the militarization, saw the racism and knew that they had to do something.'' 
 Each group also finds its particular challenge. Jewish volunteers hoping to help rebuild the temples and homes of the congregations overwhelmed the Jewish Federation of Greater New Orleans, which steered them to larger volunteer agencies and provided information at jewishnola.com. For volunteers hoping to work in southwest Louisiana, land of crawfish and boudin sausage, the site warns, ''If your volunteer group is in need of kosher food items, you will not find them in this area.''
 For Ms. Fontenot of All Congregations Together, the biggest worry is a drop in the number of volunteers as the memory of the disaster -- and the media coverage -- recedes. ''The energy behind this, the Katrina campaign, seems to be dying out,'' she said. 
 The recent smattering of good news out of the city -- Mardi Gras, the New Orleans Saints' return to the Superdome -- might mislead people around the nation to believe that all is well, she said, adding: ''We continue to need help. Neighborhoods are not back.''
 The neighborhood that Mr. Kelly and his team worked in during their October visit in Chalmette, just east of New Orleans, is certainly not back. In fact, it is doubly blighted. The Murphy Oil plant nearby accidentally released more than a million gallons of mixed crude oil into the neighborhood, rendering homes even more foul. The mud that has caked onto every surface has a tough sheen. 
 ''It's kind of like a plastic or an enamel,'' Mr. Kelly said, showing off a hunk as tough as a poker chip. The team found a videocassette glued by the muck to a wall: ''Singin' in the Rain.'' 
 The home's owner, Louis Collura, who is 63, worked alongside the team, everyone wearing white Tyvek suits, goggles and respirators. His wife, Linda Collura, who is 60, sat under the carport with the salvageable pieces of their life around her. There was a jewelry box and a punchbowl. Other items were damaged but too precious to toss, and Mr. Collura loaded them into the back of his truck: a rifle and a BB gun given to Mr. Collura by his father some 50 years before. The words Red Ryder were stamped into the stock in rope letters. 
 ''I was expecting everything to be totally destroyed,'' Mrs. Collura said happily. Having survived brain cancer in the 1980s, she said she has learned to take things as they come. 
 Inside the house, hammers and pry bars worked at Sheetrock, which gave a screech of nails on wood as it pulled away. Mrs. Collura, when asked if she would move back into the home, said, ''I doubt it very seriously.'' For now, they simply wanted the house stripped to the studs to avoid having the property seized by the parish as blighted and to qualify for the legal settlement with the oil company.
 The sweaty, dusty effort will help the Colluras, said Eric Sween, one of the muckers, but he added that there was still frustration in cleaning out a house that will, at best, be demolished. ''Our team could have been doing work in someone else's house who will move back in,'' he said. 
 The volunteers worked from the ground up, clearing the floors and then taking out counters, couches and cabinets and appliances. The Sheetrock sat in a pile in front of the house, seven feet high and growing with each passage of the wheelbarrow. A ruined couch still had its price tag; the Colluras had finished remodeling their home just weeks before the storm. 
 Everest Hunter, who came to the group from a Presbyterian church in Syracuse, breathed heavily through his mask as he drilled and pounded. ''This is like a little kid's birthday party,'' he said. ''We get to rip everything up and destroy it -- and for a good cause!''
 When asked why they come, some volunteers speak of their faith, or of their sympathy for people who have lost so much, or simply, like Mr. Kelly, of not being able to sit idly by. Especially after having been to the Gulf Coast and seen the devastation that they try to describe to friends; especially after having felt the unimaginable need of the place.
 The why is not so important, they say. What is important is to go.
 A few weeks before this third trip, Mr. Kelly sat down with two friends in Clinton who had accompanied him on his second: Steve and Nancy Hovey. In March, they had gone together and worked side by side to gut two homes, including Judith Johnson's. Sitting in their own handsome home, they reminisced over their trip: of a life's collected possessions so glommed together by water and mud that the piles had to be taken apart with pickaxes and shovels. They gave a grim laugh recalling the horrible moment when an impulsive volunteer from North Carolina decided to lighten a freezer by drilling a hole to drain it -- and sent a vile stream of liquefied rotten shrimp splashing over clothes and into boots. And they talked of praying with Mrs. Johnson after cleaning out her home.
 And they paused. They would have accompanied Mr. Kelly on the October trip, but Mr. Hovey was awaiting hip replacement surgery and would not be able to make another trip until some time in 2007. 
 But the memories had a tug to them. Nancy Hovey looked at her husband and said, ''Now we really have to go back.''
 ''I know,'' Steve replied. 
 Turning to a visitor, Nancy Hovey explained. ''It gets you.''

HEADLINE: Truth About the Trade Deficit

 BODY:
Just as the summer driving season was winding down, oil prices started to fall. The combination of less demand and lower prices was a potent mix, helping to narrow the United States' trade gap significantly in September, to $64.3 billion from $69 billion in August, according to the latest tally. 
 That's welcome news, illustrating yet another upside to curbing the nation's oil consumption. But it's also sobering. The decline in September's trade deficit was the largest in nearly two years. And yet, the United States remains squarely on track for a record trade imbalance in 2006: a projected $790 billion, compared with $717 billion last year.
The Bush administration has played down the dangers of bloated deficits. Acknowledging them would compel an effort to tame the borrow-and-spend ways of the past six years, including curbing the tax cuts that have been such a boon to the rich. 
 Far too many Congressional Democrats have blamed China's cheap currency for the trade deficit and sought a solution in protectionism. The currency complaint has a grain of truth, but it is overly simplistic and could be self-defeating if it led to global protectionism.
 So, both camps are off point. With the deficit reaching new highs and Democrats now able to wield real power, it is crucial that each side back off its constituent-pleasing myths. 
 The Bush administration needs to tell the truth about the vulnerability that comes with large deficits. Thus far, the United States has had no problem attracting money from abroad to plug the gaps. But there is no guarantee that will continue indefinitely. If foreigners chose to invest elsewhere -- like the strengthening economies of Europe or Japan -- the result would be higher interest rates and higher prices in America, perhaps sharply higher. 
 The Democrats need to take a more pragmatic view of the lopsided trade situation. The surest way to make American businesses more competitive -- and workers more secure -- is to resolve the nation's health care mess. And the government needs to update and strengthen the safety net for workers who are hurt by global competition. As recently as a few years ago, economists warned that a nation was courting a financial crisis if the size of its trade deficit exceeded 3 percent of its economy. Today, the United States' deficit is approaching 7 percent. The best way to avoid the worst is to define the problem honestly, and craft the remedies accordingly.

HEADLINE: The Fading Dream

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
''America moved me all over again -- it was an amazing place, the idea of it astounding.'' --Arthur Miller

 Rumsfeld is exiting stage left and the curtain is coming down on George W. Bush's Theater of the Absurd. A rival company is setting up shop and expectations are high.
O.K., Democrats. Now what? Inquiring minds want to know if the new troupe will make us laugh, cheer, or cry. 
 First, let's stipulate that there are limits to what the party can achieve in the next two years, even with control of both houses of Congress. But the two most important tasks facing the Democrats are doable. The first is to ensure that Congress fulfills its constitutional obligation to impose a check on the excesses of the executive. 
 The second task is to respond to the anxiety that has seeped through much of the electorate about the state of the nation. Americans are worried about the war, the political and economic situation here at home, the way the U.S. is perceived by the rest of the world, and the direction in which the country is heading.
 The Democrats didn't win the off-year elections, the Republicans lost them. And I'm convinced that the Republicans lost because while they were in charge (''Brownie, you're doing a heck of a job'') millions of Americans began to lose confidence in those things that had moved them about America -- its awesome power to do good, its ethical underpinnings, and most important, that incredible array of qualities that fell under the magical, mystical heading, the American dream.
 A real-life metaphor for what has happened to America occurred last week on the west side of Manhattan. After inviting hundreds of well-wishers to watch, officials had planned to tow the aircraft carrier Intrepid from its dock to a facility on the other side of the Hudson River, where it would undergo a major overhaul. But when the time for its departure arrived, the Intrepid, which has served for years as a popular Sea, Air and Space Museum, could not be budged. It was stuck in the mud beneath the river.
 The Intrepid was commissioned in 1943, when the U.S. still knew how to win wars. Its active history encompassed that extraordinary post-World War II period when bold leadership and a sense of common purpose transformed the U.S. and made it the envy of the world. That leadership and sense of common purpose has since been largely lost.
 The elite now send other people's children off to fight and die in wars that are unwinnable. On the home front, a two-tiered economy has been put in place in which a small percentage of the population does extremely well while a majority of working Americans are in an all-but-permanent state of anxiety about job security, pensions, the economic impact of globalization, the cost of health care, college tuition, and so on.
 For perhaps the first time in history, there is a large swath of Americans who are worried that over the long haul their children will not fare as well as they have.
 For resurgent Democrats there is no better touchstone right now than Franklin Roosevelt. He understood the corrosive effects of prolonged economic insecurity and the essential need for cooperation in the effort to build a successful society. His goal was ''to make a country in which no one is left out.''
 Roosevelt had both the vision and the political skills, including an indestructible sense of optimism, to galvanize the nation in some of its darkest hours. Those qualities have been in short supply among the terminally timid Democrats of recent years.
 Last week, the voters gave the Democrats another opportunity to lead, not just on the war in Iraq, but on such questions as how best to deal with globalization, how to make real progress toward energy independence, and how to ensure that the economic benefits of a wealthy nation are more equitably shared.
 What voters really want to know is whether the American dream will still be there for the next generation.
 In Congress over the next two years, and in the presidential campaign of 2008, the Democrats will have to respond to that question with a coherent vision of the nation's future and a cadre of leaders who, like Roosevelt, can convey that vision convincingly and optimistically.
 There's a reason why the Democratic figure generating the most excitement at the moment, Barack Obama, titled his latest book, ''The Audacity of Hope: Thoughts on Reclaiming the American Dream.''

HEADLINE: Another Hurdle for G.O.P.: A New Chairman Is Needed

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Stephen J. Minarik III will step down as state Republican chairman, party leaders said yesterday, adding new uncertainty to the party's direction following its worst defeat in New York since the Great Depression.
 Joseph N. Mondello, the longtime Nassau County Republican chairman, is the leading candidate to succeed Mr. Minarik, officials said. Some upstate Republicans raised questions about choosing a downstate leader whose track record includes losing control of his county's government, but they conceded that they knew of no other serious contenders for the job.
Mr. Mondello, 68, has the backing of Mr. Minarik and Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican State Senate majority leader, according to several officials who were granted anonymity to speak of matters that none of the three leaders want discussed publicly until they have consulted with all 62 county chairmen. Mr. Minarik plans to have the state committee meet late this month to elect a new chairman. 
 With the Democrats' sweep of statewide offices Tuesday, Mr. Bruno will become the most powerful Republican in state government, giving him considerable influence over the choice.
 Ryan Moses, executive director of the statewide party, and others confirmed that Mr. Minarik would leave the post of state chairman, which was reported by The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle yesterday. He will stay on as party chairman of Monroe County, where Rochester is located, giving him continued influence within the party statewide.
 Mr. Minarik, 46, who became state chairman two years ago, had hinted that he might step down after the election, and party leaders insisted that the results had nothing to do with his decision. In fact, some said Mr. Bruno had asked him to stay on.
 ''The chairman had made the promise to Governor Pataki and Senator Bruno that he would go through the election and then we would talk about it,'' Mr. Moses said. ''It's a tough job and Steve has four young kids.''
 But some other Republican officials had said that if Mr. Minarik did not go willingly, he should be pushed out in light of this year's travails, culminating in last week's crushing defeat.
 Spokesmen for Mr. Minarik and Mr. Bruno said that they would not comment on the resignation. Mr. Mondello did not return phone calls seeking comment.
 In January, Democrats will hold every statewide elected post, including both seats for United States Senate, for the first time since 1942. Republicans lost three Congressional seats and nearly lost three others, so Democrats will hold a 23-to-6 advantage in the New York delegation.
 The ascension of Mr. Mondello, a county chairman for more than two decades, could mark something of a comeback for a Nassau party that was once one of the nation's vaunted local political machines. For decades, it reliably delivered votes and money for statewide and national candidates, exercising near-total control of county government, and producing an Assembly speaker, a State Senate majority leader and a United States senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato.
 But the last decade has seen Democrats defeat Mr. D'Amato, capture both the county executive's post and a majority in the County Legislature, and make other inroads in Nassau -- much as they have in many other former Republican strongholds in New York. Nassau Republicans still have serious financial muscle, though, and more registered Republicans than any other county.
 In assessing Mr. Mondello, the loss of Republican control in Nassau ''was what popped into my head first,'' said Bob Smith, who recently retired as Onondaga County Republican chairman, and remains on the party's state committee.
 ''The new chair needs to be someone who has shown he can build the party back up again, county by county, be on the road every week, work more than full-time,'' he said. ''We don't have as much left to build on as we used to.''
 But Anthony Capozzi, the Broome County Republican chairman, said, like others, that he would defer to Mr. Bruno. ''I don't know Joe Mondello very well, but if Joe Bruno throws his weight behind Joe Mondello, that's good enough for me,'' he said.
 When Long Island held sway, it was not always welcomed by upstate Republicans, who saw their downstate brethren as too liberal and not concerned enough with upstate economic woes. Twelve years ago, those tensions helped Mr. Bruno topple his predecessor as Senate chief, Ralph J. Marino, who was from Nassau, and whose colleagues sometimes complained of feeling the influence of Mr. Mondello in state business.

HEADLINE: Poles Vote in Local Races Seen as First Test of Governing Coalition 

BYLINE: By JUDY DEMPSEY; International Herald Tribune

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
Poles voted Sunday in local elections that analysts said would be the first test for the 14-month-old nationalist-conservative coalition that has promised to curb corruption and rid the government of senior former Communist officials. 
 What is at stake for Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski and his identical twin, Lech, who is president, is whether their Law and Justice Party will win sufficient votes in the big towns and cities, particularly Warsaw, the capital, to allow them to proceed with their program.
They face a strong challenge in Warsaw from Civic Platform, the pro-business party. Poles are voting for mayors in 2,500 jurisdictions and for 47,000 local council members. 
 Exit polls indicated that the Law and Justice Party might prevail but that a runoff would occur in Warsaw, news agencies reported. Preliminary results were not expected until Monday. 
 Law and Justice, which the Kaczynskis founded in 2001 as a breakaway party from Solidarity, the independent anti-Communist trade union movement, narrowly defeated Civic Platform last year after winning support from large parts of eastern Poland, where unemployment is more than 20 percent in some areas. 
 It also won in the industrial centers that have had to undergo economic restructuring to become competitive. The more prosperous western parts of Poland and the large cities voted for Civic Platform.
 A clear mandate for Law and Justice would allow the government to continue the anticorruption drive that has been the main focus of its policies for 14 months. During that time, however, the government has not established any clear foreign strategy, especially regarding the European Union, Germany and Russia. 
 The government, instead of establishing a stronger voice in the European Union, has tried to forge an even closer relationship with the United States. The Kaczynskis have been negotiating with the Bush administration over whether Poland would accept on its territory elements of the American missile defense system, which the United States has deployed in rudimentary form. 
 In return, the government is seeking a special security pact. Analysts said Sunday that the victory of the Democrats in the House of Representatives and the Senate might delay completion of the system.
 Even if the Kaczynskis received a strong mandate, they would still have to contend with their coalition partners. To maintain a parliamentary majority, they have been forced to share power with the League of Polish Families, a Roman Catholic party, and the more maverick populist Self-Defense led by Andrzej Lepper. 
 Mr. Lepper, a former Communist, was dismissed from the coalition last month after repeatedly criticizing the government. Jaroslaw Kaczynski brought him back because the government could not manage without his support in Parliament.
 In Warsaw, Kazimierz Marcinkiewicz of the Law and Justice Party -- whom Lech Kaczynski forced out as prime minister in July -- is running against the Civic Platform candidate, Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz, the former chief of Poland's central bank. A leftist candidate is also running. 
 Lech Kaczynski was mayor of Warsaw until October 2005, when he was elected president. During his tenure as mayor, he banned the city's annual gay pride rally and reduced the powers of the local boroughs. Each of the major candidates have pledged to pass control back to the boroughs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Step Right Up, Ladies and Gents, to See the End of an Oddity 

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF

DATELINE: YORK, Pa. 

 BODY:
Ward Hall, the King of the Midway, has perpetrated perhaps his greatest illusion. He has risen from the dead. He has collected up his big top, rustled up the midget, dusted off the rubber fetuses and beat it back out on the road. Once again, he is the geriatric front man of the last traveling freak show in America.
 Retirement just didn't sit right.
 ''I live in Florida but I never summered in Florida, and I discovered it's too damn hot,'' says Mr. Hall, standing inside his trailer in a back lot of the York Fair in Pennsylvania. He is in a white suit, stained on the elbows and rump. Some sequins have fallen off the lapel. 
 His freak show, the World of Wonders, has been shoved by the organizers to the back corner of the fairgrounds, next to the horse stables. 
 ''I missed the road life anyway,'' he goes on, his elegant vaudevillian verbiage nearly drowned out by the sound system of the whirling Himalaya thrill ride. ''I missed my friends. I missed the money. This is what I am.'' 
 And, returning to the nation's state fair circuit after a full season off, Mr. Hall has discovered something he already knew. When he goes, it will be the end of an old-time American art form.
 Back in the heyday, in the '40s, '50s and '60s, a fair number of people with deformities were happy to let you look at them for a price. Not only were freak shows the draw of the carnival, they were the carnival. 
 But like John Henry and the steam drill, the freak show was done in by the machine: the Plunger, the Tilt-a-Whirl, the Zipper. Before them, the carnival was strictly dancing monkeys and dancing dwarves and dancing fat ladies. There was the Ossified Woman. Lobster Boy. And they made a good life. Monkey Girl managed to buy a farm. 
 There was also the bearded lady, who found a lover when her husband was out of town and shaved to please him. But it turned out the lover preferred her with the beard and rejected her, as did her husband.
 ''Her husband, coming home after a few days and seeing the beard was gone, knew something was amiss,'' Mr. Hall said. ''He chased her down the midway with a gun.'' This is how it used to be on the road.
 ''Nowadays, it's in the contracts: no freaks,'' says Mr. Hall, who believes political correctness is putting people out of work. ''Do-gooders run things. I'm telling you, this life was very good for freaks. These kind of people made money. They were hams, but they could never be actors. Who's putting a bearded lady or a one-armed girl in a leading lady role on Broadway? This way they lived a great life. No more. It's ridiculous.''
 Mr. Hall ran away from his father's fourth-floor walk-up in Denver in 1946. The father mocked the boy, telling him he would come crawling back in two weeks.
 ''Those two weeks are yet to expire,'' he says with a cackle.
 Mr. Hall joined the circus at 15, became a clown, wasn't funny, realized people didn't pay to see unfunny clowns and committed to a career of getting knives thrown at him. 
 He never married, never had children: ''I've been blessed. I have not been burdened with that, dear sir.'' 
 Instead he has spent his life on the road, most of it with his disheveled, mutton-chopped, chain-smoking business partner, Chris Christ, 58, and with Poobah, the 3-foot-7-and-a-quarter-inch dwarf who, after eating 100 skewers of fire a day, 12 hours a day, seven days a week for five decades, has no eyebrows or eyelashes to speak of, giving him the look of a pale jack-o'-lantern. Poobah has a knot on his forehead, wears a hearing aid the size of a bagel, has low blood pressure and speaks with a deep, incomprehensible gurgle. Clearly, fire has taken its toll. 
 The three men have toured Mexico, Canada and the entire United States. Today, they travel together in the same trailer, the place smelling of old men and ashes. In the off-season, they spend the winter in Gibsonton, Fla., known as Showtown U.S.A., where many freaks used to live. It is thought to be the only city in America where zoning allows people to park an elephant in the front yard.
 Some men go for golf when they grow old. Others make model boats. Mr. Hall sells fantasy. He hauls himself up from his chair, adjusts his bow tie in the mirror. Break time is over. It is his turn on the microphone. The show is never ending, going round and round like a carousel. 
 ''Technology killed the art form, too,'' Mr. Hall says, unable to get the tie straight.
 Separating Siamese twins at birth? 
 ''Can't they just leave well enough alone?'' 
 Cleft palate? 
 ''Plastic surgery.'' 
 ''It's a shame,'' he says. ''I don't know where to get my freaks.'' He advertises in the trades. Few people answer.
 Then there is the strange but true fact that American society has gone just plain freaky itself, Mr. Hall believes.
 ''The fat man -- Howard Huge -- he wanted to come out with us. But I said, 'Howard, a fat man couldn't sell 10 cents' worth of fried chicken. Everybody in America's fat.' '' 
 You want to see a fat man, Mr. Hall says, try the Cracker Barrel, you'll see a dozen at once. Same with the tattooed lady. Ditto with pierced women. Nothing special.
 Mr. Hall steps out into the sweltering sun, climbs onto the platform in front of the marquee and begins the pitch. ''Ladies and gentlemen, now come watch as Poobah will eat fire.''
 Sitting in a little pink lawn chair, Poobah looks run-down. It is nearly 100 degrees, the air as sticky as lemonade. It seems cruel, as he is only four years away from 80, but that's show business. 
 Poobah is the attraction, the only physical oddity left. Poobah is the draw that gets the dupes standing out there in flip-flops, holding on to their plastic Spider-Man blowup dolls, to pay three bucks to go inside and see a man stick a screwdriver up his nose, a sword swallower with periodontal disease, an eight-foot woman made of foam. Her left foot is broken off, and she needs a dusting. Once inside, seeing they've been lied to, people get hostile.
 ''Now, Poobah here is the king of the Pygmies,'' Mr. Hall yaps. The crowd comes closer. 
 Poobah's real name is Pete Terhurne.
 ''Poobah comes all the way from Beverly Hills.'' 
 Poobah grew up in Minnesota, met Mr. Hall at a carnival there in the mid-'50s. 
 ''Poobah is the last living munchkin from 'The Wizard of Oz.' '' 
 Poobah first saw the movie as a television rerun.
 ''He is the star of 84 Hollywood pictures, 114 television shows and numerous Broadway musicals.'' 
 Poobah couldn't sing to save his life. But Poobah says he doesn't mind. It's a living. He says he loves Mr. Hall. And it beats retirement.
 ''Now, watch as Poobah eats the fire.''
 Poobah does so for the umpteenth time today.

HEADLINE: South Ossetia Finds Independence Drive Lonely

BYLINE: COMPILED BY MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

 BODY:
A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Monday.
 TOP STORY
SOUTH OSSETIANS' INDEPENDENCE DRIVE GETS LITTLE SUPPORT: The unrecognized republic of South Ossetia held presidential elections and a controversial referendum on independence from Georgia on Sunday. While official results had not been announced by the time of publication, for the major newspapers, the outcome was obvious: the majority of South Ossetia's 92,000 residents chose sovereignty and reelected their current president Eduard Kokoiti, a strong advocate for independence. 
 Of greater concern than the actual referendum was the international response. From the outset, the European Union and the United States joined Georgia in declaring the plebiscite illegitimate, Nezavisimaya Gazeta wrote. Instead, South Ossetian officials were counting on support from Russia and other post-Soviet countries. While the Russian government stopped short of recognizing the election's legitimacy, the country's foreign ministry said in a statement that regardless of international reactions, the referendum would show the will of the people, the newspaper reported. 
 International observers from several countries, including Spain, Venezuela, Latvia, Germany and Austria, arrived in South Ossetia's capital to monitor the vote, said Kommersant. Also present, the newspaper wrote, were representatives from the other unrecognized republics in the region: Transnistria, Abkhazia and Nagorno-Karabakh. 
 Georgia took a number of steps to undermine the referendum. Georgian authorities, Gazeta reported, blocked roads through Georgian populated regions of South Ossetia and cut telephone communications. Nezavisimaya Gazeta wrote that the South Ossetian government accused Tbilisi of planning to carry out a series of terrorist attacks in the region as well as plotting to assassinate Mr. Kokoiti. Georgian officials denied the charges. 
 Georgia held an alternative referendum in South Ossetian villages with Georgian majorities: contrary to the separatist referendum, they did not mention the prospect of independence. Instead, Kommersant reported, the ballot asked voters whether or not they supported a start to negotiations with Georgia on the creation of a federal state. Georgian officials said they were surprised by the high turnout for the Tbilisi-organized referendum, the newspaper wrote. A spokesman for the South Ossetian Central Elections Commission, however, said that the alternative vote took place in just one village, Eredvi. 
 Russia and Georgia, with their relations under severe stress, used the occasion of the referendum for diplomatic wrangling. Officials in Tbilisi criticized what it called Russia's anti-Georgian policies, Nezavisimaya Gazeta wrote. They also accused Moscow of escalating tensions in the region, said Rossiiskaya Gazeta. Moscow said that Tbilisi's hard-line policies on South Ossetia had driven the republic's leaders to seek independence, the newspaper reported. 
 IN OTHER NEWS
 KOMMERSANT
 LAW STRIPS NEW PARTY OF MEMBERS: When the Russian Party of Life, the Pensioner's Party and Motherland formed the new A Just Russia party last month, newly-elected deputies from the parent organizations lost their party status under Russia's election law. Russian law says that an elected official can only represent the party for which he or she was registered at the time of elections. The deputies in question must now renounce all party affiliation or resign their posts. 
 NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
 LAW TO STRIP PARTIES OF FOREIGN FINANCING: Several State Duma deputies proposed legislation on Friday that would forbid nongovernmental organizations from financing Russian political parties during elections. Current law allows for organizations with foreign assets totaling less than 30 percent to finance political parties. President Vladimir V. Putin said as early as summer last year that he was categorically against the use of foreign funding for political activities in Russia. 
 VEDOMOSTI
 RUSSIA TO SIGN W.T.O. AGREEMENT WITH THE UNITED STATES: Russia's minister of economic development, German Gref, and an American trade representative announced on Friday that an agreement signifying the end of bilateral negotiations between Russia and the United States on Russia's accession to the World Trade Organization could be signed by the end of this week during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Hanoi, Vietnam. Mr. Gref said he hoped Russia would complete final membership talks within six months. The W.T.O.'s press secretary said, however, that the process could take much longer. 
 VREMYA NOVOSTEI
 OUR UKRAINE JOINS OPPOSITION: Members of President Viktor A. Yushchenko's Our Ukraine party on Saturday voted to join the opposition despite the president's urgings to the contrary. Nevertheless, party representatives confirmed their continued support for Mr. Yushchenko, but charged party deputies with introducing into Parliament a motion of no confidence aimed at Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich. Members almost unanimously agreed to appeal to the Constitutional Court with a request to repeal earlier constitutional amendments investing the Parliament with additional powers.

GOING PUBLIC -- Among this week's more noteworthy public offerings is one for Hertz Global Holdings, below, the car rental company that became private less than a year ago. The private equity firms that bought Hertz from the Ford Motor Company for $15 billion in cash and debt are planning to sell 88.2 million shares for $16 to $18 apiece. Another -- and more unusual -- offering that is expected is one for Nymex Holdings, which operates the futures exchange and clearinghouse, specializing in futures contracts for commodities like energy and metals. The plan is to offer 6.5 million shares for $48 to $52 a share. 


SCRUTINY FOR A MERGER -- The House Armed Services Committee has scheduled a hearing for Tuesday on the national security implications of a plan by the French company Alcatel to buy Lucent Technologies, the American maker of telephone equipment. Because Lucent does classified work for the federal government, Representative Duncan Hunter, the California Republican who is chairman of the committee, has said that he is concerned about the $11 billion deal, which would create the largest global maker of telecommunications equipment. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, which is overseen by Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary, is also reviewing the transaction.

HOT STATS -- The potentially market-moving economic reports this week include the monthly retail sales data for October on Tuesday and the Consumer Price Index, industrial production and capacity utilization, all for October, on Thursday. On tap for Friday: housing starts for October.

EARNINGS IN FASHION -- Expect a deluge of earnings reports from the nation's biggest retail chains -- like Wal-Mart Stores and Sears -- and a long list of apparel specialists and department stores. Highlights include: Tyson Foods (Monday); Abercrombie & Fitch, American Eagle Outfitters, BJ's Wholesale Club, Home Depot, HSBC Holdings, TJX Companies, Target, Saks, Staples, Vodafone and Wal-Mart (Tuesday); Limited Brands, Petsmart, Salesforce.com and Tyco International (Wednesday); Barnes & Noble, Dell, Gap, Hewlett-Packard, Sears Holdings and Starbucks (Thursday); and AnnTaylor Stores and Foot Locker (Friday).

HEADLINE: A Charity With an Unusual Interest in the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE

 BODY:
THE idea befuddled donors and Internal Revenue Service lawyers alike when Jacqueline Novogratz approached them six years ago. A philanthropic venture capital fund? 
 On one hand, the Acumen Fund would be a nonprofit charity. On the other, it would invest in companies and groups that tackled global poverty.
 It was an unusual idea to pitch to philanthropists, said Ms. Novogratz. ''They had never seen an organization like us: raising charitable money but wanting the flexibility of grants, loans and equity investments in for-profit and nonprofit organizations.'' 
 Ms. Novogratz, who has an M.B.A., has backgrounds in both in finance and philanthropy and worked as a banker at Chase Manhattan and as a manager of special projects at the Rockefeller Foundation before starting Acumen. She established a foothold in international philanthropy in 1986 when she went to Rwanda and worked on microfinance projects, long before the words ''microfinance'' or ''Rwanda'' entered the social lexicon. 
 She may have been ahead of her time. But two key people intuitively grasped the Acumen Fund's mission: Larry Page and Sergey Brin, the co-founders of Google, whom Ms. Novogratz first met at a Technology Entertainment and Design conference two years ago. During the period when Google's new charitable foundation, Google.org, was defining itself, the company's founders knew they shared a vision with Ms. Novogratz -- a desire to reinvent philanthropy and push the boundaries of how people who had done well could also do good.
 ''We were looking at different models of philanthropy,'' said Sheryl Sandberg, a vice president at Google and a Google.org board member. ''We are looking at the most efficient and effective ways to solve the world's largest problems.''
 They saw a lot of potential in the Acumen Fund, which has invested in projects meant to help people on the lowest rungs of the socioeconomic ladder: drip irrigation systems in India, rural health clinics in Kenya and a low-cost mortgage program in Pakistan. 
 Acumen models itself after a venture capital fund and brings in management and entrepreneurial expertise to help build the companies' financial independence. To that end, Acumen has a mantra on business fundamentals on how to design, price, distribute and market goods and services. But the audience it is focusing on are people who live on less than $4 a day, and Acumen's goal is to provide them affordable, critical goods and services that have otherwise been neglected by the marketplace. So when Google.org was little more than a Web page promising information to come, the Acumen Fund appeared as its first partner. To date, the Acumen Fund has been the recipient of Google.org's largest-single grant: $5 million to strengthen Acumen's operations. ''It was a really progressive and thoughtful contribution,'' Ms. Novogratz said. ''It was about building the institution.'' 
 To further cement the ties, Google announced in September that the Acumen Fund would be moving from its offices overlooking Trinity Church in the financial district of Manhattan to Google's corporate offices in the Chelsea neighborhood uptown. ''We believe that our model and Jackie's model and Acumen's model is the next wave of philanthropy,'' Ms. Sandberg said. ''It's addressing the critical needs of the world's poor, but in much more of a venture capital mode: to use seed capital to address the world's problems and to do so in a sustainable way.'' 
 Among Acumen's most notable projects is an investment in International Development Enterprises in India, a nonprofit group that manufacturers a drip irrigation system that it sells to poor farmers for under $30, a fraction of the price of traditional irrigation systems. Because the cost is so modest, the increased land productivity helps the system pay for itself in a short time, Ms. Novogratz said. ''Their lives change almost overnight if they make that investment,'' she said. ''They see their income double or triple -- that allows them enough income to buy a second system. That is how they accumulate wealth.'' So far, more than 30,000 units have been sold.
 In the twin worlds of philanthropy and venture capital, where billion is a commonly used measure, the Acumen Fund can seem modest. It has about 29 full-time staff members and seven fellows in offices in New York, India, Pakistan and, soon, Kenya. Of the $40 million dollars it has raised since it formally began in 2001, it has distributed only around $20 million -- a small amount by traditional philanthropic standards. Yet Ms. Novogratz explained that the firm's approach was expensive. ''The business acumen costs money,'' she said. ''We are highly labor intensive.'' Many of the managers hold M.B.A's and have resumes studded with stints at Goldman Sachs, Credit Suisse First Boston, McKinsey.
 Rather than simply focusing on potential profitability, Acumen evaluates projects for social impact, financial sustainability, replicability and what Ms. Novogratz calls ''breakthrough insights'' -- knowledge that can be applied elsewhere. 
 For example, they have spent a lot of time understanding when the poor act like mainstream customers and when they don't. Another insight prompted them to eliminate grants, and limit Acumen to loans and equity investments. ''Grants do not provide the same amount of clarity of expectations or financial discipline, or the same power as a conduit into more traditional financial markets,'' Ms. Novogratz said. 
 ''What we need in this sector is these kinds of ideas and models to get others to think frankly of doing their business in a similar way,'' said Allen S. Grossman, a professor at Harvard Business School who studies entrepreneurship in the social sector.
 Those insights are critical to charting new territory, said Dr. Grossman, who also advises Acumen. ''You can't take business practices and superimpose them when it comes to social issues,'' he said. ''What they do is a very effective social adaptation so that there is not a conflict between good business practices and achievement of a social mission.'' 
 But often local entrepreneurs do feel tension between business and philanthropy, said Yasmina Zaidman, who manages water projects for Acumen. They are caught because nonprofits tell them to ''stop making money off the poor'' while business executives say, ''If you want to make money, get serious, stop messing around in the rural areas,'' Ms. Zaidman added. ''They haven't been supported or acknowledged.''
 Like any investment fund, Acumen has its disappointments. Of 21 projects, 15 are still active. Last year, for example, Acumen pulled out of a fluoride filtration company in India when the company changed its strategy and started pursuing subsidized government contracts. ''It was frustrating, but that lesson has influenced us so much since then,'' Ms. Zaidman said. 
 An earlier project, centered around a $42 hearing aid, failed to take off in India despite the product's relatively low cost. ''We were jumping up and down thinking we hit the ball out of the park,'' Ms. Novogratz said. Acumen helped distribute 10,000 of the hearing aids, but low demand and a poor distribution network prevented it from becoming an independent business. ''We learned that technology alone does not solve problems,'' she said, ''and that what is as important -- or more important -- than the technology is the business model for bringing services to poor people.''
 While Ms. Novogratz was in Rwanda, she helped women there set up a bakerycalled Duterimbere, which means ''to go work with enthusiasm'' in the local Rwandan language. ''We cornered the snack food market,'' she said. 
 Her farewell present from the women was a tapestry depicting scenes from the bakery, the town and a local school. It blends into the Acumen office decor -- a mix of the dot-com aesthetic of Aeron chairs and ethnic handicrafts from Ms. Novogratz's travels. Glancing at the Rwandan tapestry, Ms. Novogratz said, ''Unfortunately, all the women created it were killed in the genocide, so it's even more important.'' She added, ''Acumen Fund is my prayer in response to genocide and what happened in Rwanda.''
